On the 10th of August I employed the prisoner to take a horse to Galley-quay, to go to Sunderland; he had two sovereigns to pay the expences - he did not put the horse on board, but put it at livery, and I had the bill to pay for it: I did not see him again till the 21st of March; I put my hand on his shoulder, and said,"Halloo, my friend!" he looked up and said, "Will you have any gin" - I said, "I will gin you to the watchman;" he said he had spent some of the money, and the rest he had lost; I found the horse at livery the day after he took it.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not send me to No. 11, Catherine-court, Trinity-square, to ascertain where the vessel laid? A. No such thing; I told you to go and put the horse on board, and I would give you half a sovereign when you had done.

Prisoner's Defence. He gave me this horse, and told me to go to the place and inquire; I saw two gentlemen, who said the vessel was not to sail for three days, but I had better wait to see if the gentleman belonging to it would come there; I walked the horse about for an hour, and then the gentlemen came and said, "You had better put that horse up," which I did; I met a shopmate, and got rather too much - I do not know what became of the money, nor myself either hardly; I have since then broken my arm, and have been three months in the hospital - I have not had an opportunity of returning the money; if I had meant to have made a theft of it I should not have left the saddle and bridle in the ostler's hands.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Six Months .

887.
EDWARD HIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 black coat, value 2l. , the goods of
William Presland
.

WILLIAM PRESLAND
. I lost a black coat from Goodge-street, on the 6th of April.

THOMAS PRESLAND
. I saw the prisoner take the coat, and pursued him till he came to Berners-street, where he was taken - I never lost sight of him.

JOHN CHARLES MITCHELL
. I was walking up the street, and met the prisoner running; I made a grasp athim, but he got by me, and threw this coat against the rails.

THOMAS WILLETT
. I was in the street, about ten minutes after nine o'clock; I heard Stop thief! called, and saw the prisoner running on the other side; I went over, and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I heard a cry of Stop thief! a man came and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Three Months .

888.
CHARLES JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February . 1 looking-glass, value 12s. , the goods of
George Payne
.

GEORGE PAYNE
. I am a broker , and live in Princes-street, Drury-lane
. On the 25th of February, I saw a person running out with this glass, about twenty minutes before six o'clock; I had seen it safe a quarter of an hour before; I went into the street, and saw the prisoner walking with it under his arm - I went up to him, and asked who it belonged to; he said he could not help it.

WILLIAM ECKETT
. I took the prisoner. I found these keys on him - one of them is a picklock-key for a drawer.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

889.
SARAH MASON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 2 blankets, value 10s. , the goods of
John Walker
.

ELIZA WALKER
. I am the wife of John Walker, of Sutton-street, Soho
. I lost a pair of blankets on the 8th of April, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning - I had seen them safe about ten minutes before, on the bed in the first floor front room; the prisoner had asked me to allow her to wait there for a friend, and I took her up stairs.

GEORGE BLACKMAN
. I took charge of the prisoner at a house in Crown-street, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning; she had these blankets under her clothes - she did not give me any account of them, but she told the Magistrate she bought them of a Jew in Monmouth-street.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. This woman said a man at her house wanted a girl, and if I would go he would give me a little money; I went, but did not stay long - I bought the blankets of a Jew in Monmouth-street.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

890.
FLORENCE McCARTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 2 pairs of flannel drawers, value 7s.; 1 flannel shirt, value 4s., and 2 shirts, value 3s. , the goods of
Ellen Fortheringham
.

ELLEN FORTHERINGHAM
. I am a widow . On the 23d of March I went into the yard to take these things off the line, at half-past nine o'clock, and they were gone - I had seen them safe at eight; these are the articles.

WILLIAM SUMMERS
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house, with these things in a wet state; he said he got them from his wife in the morning in a tiff - I asked if he knew what marks were on them; he said there were no marks - I made inquiries, and found the prosecutrix.

BENJAMIN PORFITT
. I was in Ratcliff-highway; the prisoner and these things were given to me in charge by Mr. Hart of Ratcliff-highway.

Prisoner's Defence. I left work about seven o'clock; a man came and stopped me, and said, "Sailor, will you buy any things?" I said."What are they?" and said I had no money; he said if I could shew him where to sell them he would give me 1s.; I took him to Mr. Hart's, whom I had bought some things of; he then said he was ashamed to take them in - I took them in, and Mr. Hart detained me.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Six Months .

891.
RICHARD PLATT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , one 5l. Bank note , the property of
William Sinclair
.

WILLIAM SINCLAIR
. I am a discharged soldier . On the 12th of March, I gave the prisoner a 5l. Bank note to fetch me change at the Commercial tap, as I did not know the value of change so well - I had known him about a month; he and I slept in the same room - he brought me no change, but I saw him next morning, between eight and nine o'clock; I asked him for the note or the change - he denied having had it; the number of the note begins with a 2; I am not a scholar, but I think there are four more figures.

SARAH WHITELOW
. I am servant at the Commercial inn; I gave the prisoner five sovereigns for a 5l. note - he said it was for a person whom he lodged with.

JAMES GILLMAN
. I took the prisoner; he said he had no note from the prosecutor, but he had it from Mrs. Brotherington; I went there, and she said she did not give it him - the prisoner then said he had it from a gentleman, but he did not know where he lived; 3s. 4 1/2d. were found upon him - this is the note; it is number 29,950.
Prisoner's Defence. I was quite intoxicated, and I do not recollect taking any note to get change.
GUILTY. Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 1 Month .

892.
ALEXANDER ROSS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 2 pewter pots, value 2s. , the goods of
John Ware
.

JOHN WARE
. I am a publican . On the 10th of April the officer took the prisoner into custody in St. Katharine Docks; there were two pots of mine found on him; he said he had picked them up in the street, and a cart had gone over them.

CHARLOTTE HEIMEY
. I am the wife of
John Heimey
; he keeps a marine-store shop in East Smithfield. The prisoner brought these pewter pots to our shop on Friday last; I did not see any name on them till the officer came in - I then saw "J. Ware" on them; I gave them to Haylock.

THOMAS HAYLOCK
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner in St. Katharine's Docks; he seemed to be beating something - I went near the place, and before I got there he was gone; I afterwards saw him go to amarine-store shop, in Nightingale-lane - these are the pots; they are squeezed double.
Prisoner's Defence. I found them in the street, and one of them was as if a wheel had gone over it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Month .

893.
MAURICE SHEEDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 4 iron stove-bottoms, value 3s., and 7 iron turn-buckles, value 6d. , the goods of
Margaret Nash
.

MARGARET NASH
. I am a widow , and deal in ironmongery . On the 3d of March these things were within four inches of my door; I had put them out myself - I was at my dinner, and a witness called out "Mrs. Nash, do you know the person who has taken these things from your door?" I said No, went out, and gave an alarm; when the prisoner was brought back he said it was the first time, and he hoped I would be merciful.

RICHARD BURTON
. I saw the prisoner take these articles - he walked very fast by me, and I went and called to know if Nash knew the young man - I heard a voice say No- the prosecutrix then came out; the prisoner carried them in front of him: I followed him, and saw him drop the things.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined One Month .

894.
SAMUEL TASKER
was
indicted for embezzlement .

CHARLOTTE PHILLIPS
. I am the wife of
Horatio Nathaniel Phillips
, a publican - the prisoner was in our service as waiter ; my husband is not here.

JOHN WEATHERBY
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner - he asked if I had a warrant against him; I said I had not - he said he would go and see Mr. Phillips, and hear what he would say.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Then he went with you? A. Yes; Mr. Phillips asked if he had got any friends who would come forward to see the money paid that he owed him - I believe he owed him about 21l.; he said he had got nobody to come forward - Mr. Phillips ordered me to take him into custody, but he did not appear before the Magistrate; he said nothing to him about the 6s.

ANDREW WATSON
. On the 25th of March, between one and two o'clock, I paid the prisoner 6s.
Cross-examined. Q. What was it for? A. For lodging; I took no receipt - I made a memorandum of it myself.

CHARLOTTE PHILLIPS
re-examined. The prisoner had been in our service two years; he ought to account on Saturday night to me or my husband for monies received- he absconded on the Saturday night.
Cross-examined. Q. If the 6s. had been accounted for to Mr. Phillips it would have been just the same as if it had been paid to you? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

895.
SAMUEL TASKER
was again indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of March , 15 shillings and 10 sixpences , the monies of
Horatio Nathaniel Phillips
.

CHARLOTTE PHILLIPS
. The prisoner was in our service, and was in the habit of receiving 1l. in silver to go to Mr. Gurney's factory to receive scores; he had it on the night of the 28th of March, and did not return.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to the bar and Mrs. Phillips gave me fifteen shillings, eight sixpences, and 1s. in copper, which I never did account for certainly; but she never gave me 1l. worth of silver.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Six Months .

896.
HENRY WISKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 1 mill wright's tool, called a square, value 6s. , the goods of
William Lockie
.

WILLIAM LOCKIE
. I am a millwright . I lost a square on the 25th of February, from the back room of my house- the prisoner lodged in my house two or three days; he had no right in that room.

RICHARD ROPE
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this square on the 25th of February; I do not know from whom.

THOMAS WATERLOW
. I am an officer. I took up the prisoner and charged him with stealing this square; he said there were other persons in the house beside him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written defence, denying the charge.
NOT GUILTY .

897.
ANN ANDREWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March , 1 shawl, value 7s.; 3 aprons, value 2s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Betty Barnes
; 1 shawl, value 15s., and 1 table-cloth, value 5s., the goods of
Robert Back
.

ROBERT BACK
. I lost a shawl and table-cloth previous to the 25th of March, from a house where I resided; the prisoner lived there as servant to Mr. Jenkins - these are them; the table-cloth has my initials, and the shawl is like my wife's, but I will not swear positively to that.

BETTY BARNES
. I lost a shawl, five aprons, and a handkerchief, from the same house; the prisoner was servant there - these are the articles.

GEORGE SHEPPERD
. I am a pawnbroker. This red shawl was pawned by a woman - I cannot say by whom.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three aprons and a silk handkerchief; I cannot say by whom they were pawned.

RICHARD ROPE
. This shawl was pawned with me by a woman; I do not know who.

SAMUEL SHARWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. This tablecloth was pawned with me - I believe by the prisoner.

ROBERT DUKE
. I took up the prisoner at the house, and desired her to get me a light to look for some other property; while she was looking for the candle she went to the bottom of the kitchen stairs - I saw her throw her hand back; I went to the place and found between twenty and thirty duplicates - I said "You have just thrown these away, what did you do that for?" she said, because she did not want me to know she had them; they were for this property.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Judgment Respited .

898.
ANN ALLGOOD
and
MARIA TOOMEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 pair oftrousers, value 2s. 5d.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s. 6d., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
Edward Randall
.

EDWARD RANDALL
. I am a painter . I lost this property on the 7th of April, from the Bag of Nails public-house, at Pimlico
- I did not get drunk nor go to sleep; the articles were tied in a bundle; Toomey took them while the other was sitting alongside of me; they went away in different roads.

JAMES KING
. I am a labourer. The two prisoners came up to the prosecutor in the Park, and went on to the first public-house; they staid there about half an hour, and then went on to the Bag of Nails - I did not go in at either of the houses.

CHARLES BANKS
. I was at the Bag of Nails, between three and four o'clock on the 7th of April: the two prisoners and the prosecutor came in; they called for half a pint of rum - Toomey passed as his wife, and the other as his sister; a man there wanted to shake hands with the prosecutor, and the prisoners fell aboard of him; Toomey took the bundle and went out; Allgood put her hand into his pocket, and they both ran off in different directions - the prosecutor was sitting still; he was intoxicated.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. The two prisoners pawned all this property at our house, on the 7th of April, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening; they were not tipsy.

CHARLES AUGUSTUS DORRINGTON
. The prisoner Allgood was given into my charge at near twelve o'clock at night - there was nothing found on her; she was intoxicated.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ALLGOOD'S Defence. I met this man in St. James'-park - we were both very much intoxicated; he caught hold of us both, and took us to a public-house; he brought us all kinds of liquor; I do not know how I got home - but as to the property, I had none.

TOOMEY's Defence. I do not know how I came by the bundle; I think he must have given it me - I had no notion of robbing him; we had been all drinking the whole of the day, and Bankes was like the rest; we were all intoxicated.

ALLGOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Three Months .

TOOMEY -
GUILTY . Aged 36.

899.
JAMES BEDDOES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 4 caps, value 5s.; 3 petticoats, value 7s.: 1 pair of stays, value 3s.: 1 collar, value 1s., and 1 pocket, value 1s. , the goods of
John Rogers
.

ELIZABETH ROGERS
. I am the wife of John Rogers. On the 23d of March I had packed up the articles stated in a band-box, to take to the owner; I was driving them in a cart, about a quarter to nine o'clock - I have seen the articles since; these are them.

CHRISTIAN PODZUS
. The watchman brought this property and the prisoner to the watch-house; I asked him what he had to say; he said Nothing.

MICHAEL LYON
. I am a watchman. A gentleman brought the prisoner into Hand-court, and gave him to me, with this property; the owner was not there - I took him to the watch-house; I saw the cart, but did not see him take any thing; but that gentleman did.

Prisoner's Defence. I was crossing up Red Lion-street, and two lads were fighting in the road; one said,"I shan't carry this;" and another said, "I shan't;" I said, "What is in it;" and they said, "Will you have it;" I took it, and this gentleman took me.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

900.
ELEANOR COTTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 1 gown, value 4s., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
Sarah Porton
.

MARY JACKSON
. The prisoner came to me, on the 24th of February, about twelve o'clock, and asked for Louisa's things; I said I had not any of them - she then asked for Sally's blue gown and apron; I gave them to her, supposing
Sarah Porton
had sent her.

SARAH PORTON
. I had never seen the prisoner that day; she used to work in the same house as me - I did not send her for the things.

BOYD SILVESTER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 2d of March, she had this apron on - I asked where the gown was; she told me she went for some things, and got these in mistake; that
Samuel Smith
, who was outside, said "Keep them;" they took them to the Minories, and pawned the gown.

EDWARD PERKINS
. I am a pawnbroker. I took this gown in pawn from the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

901.
JANE HARVEY
was indicted for
stealing. on the 21st of March , 2 shirts, value 10s. , the goods of
Mary Whitingham
.

MARY WHITINGHAM
. I live in Homer-street
, and am a poor working woman. The prisoner, whom I had known before, came to see me on the 21st of March, and while she was there I brought some shirts into the room, in a basket; they belonged to my landlord; I had them to wash - she remained from nine o'clock in the morning till two or three; these are the shirts.

WILLIAM PARKER
. I am a pawnbroker. These shirts were pawned with me, on the evening of the 21st of March, to the best of my belief by the prisoner. I gave her this duplicate.

ROBERT CRAIG
. I took the prisoner, and found this duplicate on her.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

902.
JOHN CLANCEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 silver watch, value 4l., and 1 seal, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas Chapman
, from his person .

JAMES LOGAN
. I was in Mr.
Thomas Chapman
's parlour, on the 14th of March, and saw his watch taken out of his pocket by the prisoner; there were no other persons there - the prisoner was well acquainted with his house, and I thought he took it to give to a lad at the bar, but he put it into his pocket, and went out; I told him to leave him alone, and he said it was all right: Mrs. Chapman came in and searched her husband's pockets, and sent for the watchman - I was taken up; I did not then tell her who tookit; they let me go, and then I told - the prisoner came in again, and sat down by me; I stated what I had seen, and he was taken.

CHARLES WESTBURY
. I was in the parlour - I saw the prisoner put his hat under the landlord's head, as a pillow, and then he took his watch and put into in his own pocket; Logan said "What business have you with the watch? let the man alone;" the prisoner said it is all right.

WILLIAM SUMMERS
. I took the prisoner, and found 4s. 6d. on him, and some halfpence; he said he had no knowledge of the watch; Logan said he thought he had done it out of a lark, and was going to leave it at the bar.

Prisoner's Defence. Westbury would swear my life away, if I had twenty lives; he is jealous of me about his wife - I came out to market, there was an uproar in the house, and the watch was gone: Logan never said I took it, till I came into the room again.
NOT GUILTY .

903.
WILLIAM COTTERELL
and
THOMAS McCARTHY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 6 hanks of iron wire, value 7s. , the goods of
Alexander Hawkins
.

ALEXANDER HAWKINS
. I am an ironmonger , and live in Chiswell-street
. I lost six hanks of iron wire on the 24th of February; I saw Cotterell take it - and while he took it, McCarthy came to the door and said, "Now then, come along, come along;" McCarthy took it on his shoulder; I went and took him with it; Cotterell came for some wire, and remained for it - but I am positive he gave this wire to McCarthy.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Had not Cotterell been bargaining for some wire? A. Yes; he had been asking for some; I had seen him over the way at my other premises, and my lad had gone over with him; I think it impossible that McCarthy could hear him ask for it - it was while my lad was gone for some wire that Cotterell gave McCarthy this; there were three candles in the shop, two in the window and one on the counter; I had been lying in wait for them - I ran out of my private door, and collared McCarthy; they could not see me.

JOSEPH DEERING
. I am in the service of Mr. Hawkins. On the 24th of February, Cotterell came in the evening and asked me for a quarter of a pound of 16 or 17, meaning some wire - I said, "It is not here, you had better come over the way;" I went with him, and my master followed us - he went with me round to the private door, and I went into the shop; my master went and looked through a crack in the door - I went to serve Cotterell; he took the gauge, and said, "There is none here will do, you had better go and get some;" I went up into the kitchen, and presently I heard a scuffle and came down - I saw my master had got both the prisoners; the wire was on the shop floor.
Cross-examined. Q. You were in the shop when you gave the gange to Cotterell? A. Yes; a person going by might see the bargain we made - he appeared like a customer.

ALEXANDER HAWKINS
re-examined. Q. What time was this? A. Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening; McCarthy did not run - he made no resistance; I said, "Now, you villain, I have got you at last;" he said the lad in the shop asked him to take the wire for him, but he did not say where to.
JOHN BROWN. I am an officer. I took the prisoners and property.
Cotterell put in a written paper, acknowledging the offence, and pleading poverty in extenuation.
McCARTHY's Defence. Cotterell asked me to carry the wire, and knowing him, I took it.

COTTERELL -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

McCARTHY -
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Transported for Seven Years .

904.
WILLIAM CARPENTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , 1 pair of boots, value 10s. , the goods of
Charlotte Dudman
, widow .

THOMAS OVINGTON
. I am foreman to
Charlotte Dudman
, who keeps a shoe-warehouse in Whitechapel
. On the 12th of March I sat down to tea - I turned my head and caught a glimpse of this lad running out of the shop with a pair of boots; I did not lose sight of him till I took him; he said a boy gave them to him.

JAMES FOWLER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a boy take these shoes - I ran after him up George-street - he dropped them, and I took them up.
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Whipped and Discharged.

905.
LUKE CARTLIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 2 pairs of trousers, value 10s. , the goods of
William Jeanes
.

HARRIET JEANES
. I am the wife of
William Jeanes
. On the 6th of March I saw the prisoner get over my shop counter as I was at the cradle with my baby - I ran out and collared him; these trousers were lying down at the street door - I had seen them safe two or three minutes before, hanging on a rail in the window; he must have gone round the counter for them.

WILLIAM DANFORD
. I have the trousers, and took the prisoner; he said he had merely gone to inquire for the name of Lewis; I asked his reason for going out before some one came - he said there was no one there, and he could not wait.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to inquire for Lewis, who owed me a little money - I waited two minutes and no one came; I came out - as for the trousers, I never saw them.
GUILTY . Aged 56.
Confined Six Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

906.
HARRIET GEORGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 9 silver spoons, value 50s. , the goods of
Joseph Elmes
.

JOSEPH ELMES
. I live in Somerset-place, New-road, Whitechapel
. The prisoner was our servant - she left us on the 14th of February, without warning, and I missed nine silver spoons.

FRANCIS RAMSAY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tottenham-court-road. I have two table and two dessert-spoons, pawned by an elderly female.

HENRY JOHN PARKER
. I have two tea-spoons pawned, I believe, by the prisoner.

EDWIN SALMON
. I am a pawnbroker of London-street, Fitzroy-square. I have three tea-spoons pawned by an elderly female.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
. I was applied to, and took the prisoner in about six weeks afterwards. I asked if she was the person who had robbed Mr. Elmes; she said Yes, and she had sent the duplicates back as she thought it would be better for her.
MR ELMES. I received them in a sheet of paper.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Confined One Year .

907.
GEORGE GRAY
and
JOHN THOMAS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 1 gun, value 50s. , the goods of
David Farrow
.

EDWARD GROVE
. I am a shopman to Mr.
David Farrow
, salesman of High Holborn
. On the 26th of March I was cleaning the window, and saw the two prisoners in company; Gray laid hold of a cord which secured this gun - I told the young man in the shop I thought they were going to steal it, and immediately I saw Thomas pass with the gun in his possession - I pursued, and caught Gray in the road; he slipped from me, and ran up a court- he was stopped there by two or three persons, but got away from them; I tried to stop him as he returned, but he struck at me - I stooped, and he struck his hand through a square of glass; he ran into Holborn, and was taken.

JOHN BROOKS
. I was in the shop, and saw Thomas pass with the gun; I pursued - and as he got to Turnstile I caught him with the gun in his hand; he dropped it, and we had a severe struggle; but I brought him back.

ALFRED MARTIN
. I saw Gray run up Red Lion-street pursued by the witness; I stopped him - he seemed very much flurried; I asked what was the matter - he said somebody gave him a punch of the head: I said if he would go back we would ascertain what that punch of the head meant - I took him back, and received this gun.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GRAY's Defence. I was going home, and that young man took hold of me. I pushed him away, went down a court, and was taken - I had nothing to do with it, and was not near the shop.

GRAY -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

THOMAS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

908.
MARY MORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 1 cloak, value 7s.; 1 gown, value 1s.; 2 petticoats, value 1s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 1s., and 1 cap, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Nelder
.

ELIZABETH NELDER
. I am single , and lodge in Zion-terrace, Brunswick-square
; the prisoner lodged in the back parlour. On the 28th of February I lost these articles; the prisoner had been there from the Saturday before, and went away on Saturday - I missed my cloak first, and the other things on the Tuesday following; they had been in my room - the prisoner was taken at her mother's in about a fortnight; I had known her before, but she was no particular friend of mine - I was in the front parlour when she went away.

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEPHENS
. I heard of the robbery, and found the prisoner at No. 19, St. Helena-place, Spafields, about eleven days after she had taken the things; this gown, cap, and shoes, were on her person.

WILLIAM COOMBS
. I am a shopman to Mr Fleming, a pawnbroker; the prisoner pawned a cloak, but it was redeemed the day afterwards.

HENRY HAYES
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Goswell-street. I have a white petticoat; the prisoner pawned at our house, and I think she pawned this; it is in the name of Miller, in which name she always pawned - I do not think we have another person who pawns in that name.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's. She is a girl of the town; she gave me these things when she was in bed.
The prisoner then put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutrix had sent her to pledge the property to procure victuals for them both.

ELIZABETH NELDER
. Upon my solemn oath I never permitted her to pawn any thing of mine; we were not on intimate terms - we have taken something to eat together; I am under the protection of a gentleman.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

909.
JOHN HENRY SWAKENBERG
was
indicted for stealing, on the 4th of March , 1 ham, value 12s. , the goods of
John Palin
.

SARAH PALIN
. I am the wife of
John Palin
, cheesemonger of Brunswick-street, Hackney-road
. I saw the prisoner take a ham from our shop about a yard within the door at eight o'clock, in the evening of the 4th of March - I was at the parlour door; I gave the alarm, but he was not taken at that time - the ham has not been found; I am certain he is the man - he was taken on the Friday following.
Prisoner. Q. What sort of a coat had the man on? A. You had a cap, with one or two places torn the same as when you were taken.

JAMES ORFORD
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner in Hackney-road; he denied the charge - Mr. Palin, who was with me, went for his wife, who came and identified him.

JOHN PALIN
. When I went home this ham was missed. My wife described the man to me, and it was in consequence of her description he was taken; I suppose he was taken a quarter of a mile from my shop.

Prisoner's Defence. The officer came and said,"Where is that ham?" I said, "What ham?" and they sent for the woman, who said I was not the man; but her husband made her swear I was.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Six Weeks .

910.
THOMAS WILCOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 1 shawl, value 12s.; 1 gown, value 8s.; 3 shirts, value 12s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 6d.; 1s. 6d. in silver monies, and 12 penny-pieces , the property of
Henrietta Beerman
.

HENRIETTA BEERMAN
. I live in York-street, Commercial-road
- I take in washing ; I have known the prisoner from nine years of age - he did lodge with me. On the 6th of April I missed this property from different places: I have lived five years next door to the prisoner's mother.

THOMAS COX
. I have two shirts pawned with me by the prisoner, at Mr. Latter's, Commercial-road, on the 1st of April, and on the 28th of March.

THOMAS STIMSON
. I am an officer. I had information, and took the prisoner in East Smithfield; I found some duplicates on him - he said he had pawned these things,(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had been seduced by bad companions to commit the offence.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury, believing it to be his first offence .
Confined One Month .

911.
JANE MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 6 lbs. weight of bacon, value 1s.; and 3 lbs weight of bread, value 6d. , the goods of
Frances Nash
.

FRANCES NASH
. I am single . I lost these things from Charles-street, Westminster
, from a closet on the first floor.

MARY SMITH
. I am landlady of the house. On the 8th of April I saw the prisoner going out of the passage - she was quite a stranger; I asked what she had got in her apron? she said, if I would let her go she would give it me, as it was all she had taken: I brought her back, and she emptied it out; she begged very hard to be let go.

JOHN WILDMAN PAINE
. I took the prisoner with the articles.
Prisoner's Defence. It was distress; I had been in the hospital with a broken arm.
GUILTY . Aged 58.
Confined One Month .
OLD COURT.
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 15.
Third Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

912.
THOMAS GODWIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 3 crowns, 12 half-crowns, 35 shillings, and 40 sixpences, the monies of
John White
, in his dwelling-house .

JOHN WHITE
. I keep an eating-house in James-street, Oxford-street
. I have known the prisoner about three years and a half; he lived with me on the 31st of March; this money was in a drawer behind the till, in a bag - it contained 5l. 10s., all in silver - but what coins I cannot say; I counted it just before I put it into the drawer; at half-past three o'clock, or a quarter to four, in the afternoon of the 31st of March, which was the last time I saw it; the prisoner was not in the house then, but came home in the evening, between six and seven, and about eleven I missed the money; the prisoner had been out - he had been at home from six to ten o'clock; I think he was at home when I missed my money - he was in a little parlour; I went into the parlour, my wife was there with him - I asked her, in his presence, if she had been to the till, and taken out the silver? she said, No; I said,"Then I am robbed;" my wife came out of the parlour into the shop; the prisoner said he was very sorry to hear it: he stopped about five minutes, and then went to bed; I went up that night to him in bed, and asked him if he had been and taken my money? he said No, and then said, "Why do you think I took it?" I said, "My suspicions are on you, Mr. Godwin;" he asked why I suspected him - I said, I considered he was the person, because there was nobody in the shop but him and my maid; he said he was innocent: after that my wife went up to him - I was not present; he dressed himself, and came down stairs; I then got the watchman to take him to the watch-house; he dressed himself of his own accord; he kept on saying he was innocent of it - he came back again; he was not searched at the watch-house; he stopped in the house a little while, and then I took him and the servant to the watch-house again; he kept denying it; I brought them both back, and then he went to bed - he got up about eight o'clock next morning; the officer came and saw him in the parlour; I saw the officer search him in the dining-room, and find 9s. 5 3/4d. in his pocket - then he took off his trousers and found three sovereigns in one pocket - I said my money was all in silver: he then said he had changed the silver he took from me into gold - we continued to search, and found 20s. in silver in one of his trousers pockets, and 21s. 6d. in the other; he said it was mine, and begged for mercy.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Before he said any thing about the money, had you not said it would be better for him to confess, and you would give him a sovereign into the bargain? A. I did; he could have concealed the money if he liked; he bore an honest, industrious character.
COURT. Q. When was it you said he had better confess? A. The evening that I missed the money; not a word was said to him in the morning.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer. I was sent for on the 1st of April, about eight o'clock in the morning, to the prosecutor's house, and found the prisoner there; I searched him, and found 9s. 5 3/4d. in his waistcoat pocket, three sovereigns in his right-hand breeches pocket, and 2l. in silver in his other pockets; I said I understood the money was all in silver; he then said, "Yes, it was so; pray forgive me, Mr. White, it was all your money; I have changed 3l. in silver for sovereigns:" no promise or inducement was held out to him in my presence - I found four shillings more on him than was lost.

JURY to
JOHN WHITE
. Q. Was the drawer locked? A. No; he had been out for a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

913.
CHARLOTTE INMAN
and
JOHN McFEDYEN
were indicted for the
wilful murder of
Sarah Ewen
.

The charge against the prisoners was causing the death of the said
Sarah Ewen
, by administering certain noxious drugs, and the use of an instrument for the purpose of causing abortion, the particulars of which, it is presumed, are best omitted.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

914.
ELEANOR FOX
and
MARY STEEL
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Edward McQuillen
, on the King's highway, on the 31st of March , at St. Giles in the Fields , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 tooth-pick, value 2d.; 1 button value 1/4d.; 1 penny-piece, and 1 half-penny, his property .

EDWARD McQUILLEN
. I live at No. 20, Buckeridge-street, St. Giles'. On the 31st of March I was in a public-house at the corner of Plumtree-street, and saw the prisoner Fox there; I came out of the house between eightand ten o'clock - I had been drinking, and cannot state the time I came out; two women followed me - Fox was one; Fox asked me to go home with her; I told her I would not - that I lodged convenient: and when I turned round the corner into the street I lived in, the woman who was with her put her hand into my pocket; I sang out for the watchman - I do not know what she took from my pocket; Fagan the officer came up immediately: I had been drinking for two days together - I was nearly drunk when this happened.

FRANCIS FAGAN
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. On the 31st of March I was on duty in Buckeridge-street, St. Giles', I heard a cry of Watch! between ten and eleven o'clock at night, and saw Fox with her arms round the prosecutor's body; she stood behind him, with her arms clasped round his body, holding him behind - Steel was in front of him, rifling his pockets: I did not think him drunk - there was not much difference in him than there is now; I took hold of Fox, while my partner took Steel; I searched Fox, but found nothing on her: when I took hold of her a button dropped from her - I searched Steel, and observed she had something in her month: she denied that she had - I insisted on her opening her mouth, and shewing me what she had; she refused to do so, and I used force; after struggling with her for a quarter of an hour, I succeeded in getting from her mouth a tooth-pick and three halfpence farthing: I secured, and took them to the watch-house - the tooth-pick is here; Wheatley found a duplicate in her hand.

WILLIAM WHEATLEY
. I was with Fagan, and saw the prisoners together, round the prosecutor, at the corner of George-street; I took Fox, and found a duplicate in Steel's right hand, and a piece of tobacco; the prosecutor said they were his, in the prisoner's presence.

DANIEL RIERDAN
. I was with Fagan and Wheatley. I picked up a button which laid on the ground, between Steel and Fox; I had seen Steel throw something away, but cannot say whether it was a button; I thought it was money - it sounded like a shilling; she threw it away directly we came up - we found no money, as the crowd collected and the street was muddy; the button was one of a Chelsea pensioner's; I have had it ever since.

EDWARD NEYLON
. I am a copper-plate printer. As I was going home I saw the prisoners going along with this man; I stopped and looked after them - I saw Steel following the prosecutor; I saw Steel with her left hand round the prosecutor's body, and her right hand in his trousers pocket; Fox followed behind at a distance - I afterwards saw them in Fagan's custody.

EDWARD MCQUILLEN
. This tooth-pick belongs to me; I have had it two months - I know it by a crack on one side of it, and two marks on each end; I had it in my pocket all day, and had it in my hand several times: this duplicate is mine - it is for two silk handkerchiefs, pawned that day for 2s.; I had a button similar to this in my pocket: it came off this coat: I bought this coat of a Chelsea pensioner - I do not know what money I lost; I had the change of shilling out of three or four quarterns of gin.
Prisoner STEEL. Q. Did you not want to go home with me that night, and I said you should not? A. I do not recollect speaking to her at all.
FOX's Defence. The man knows I never touched him; this woman asked me to go and have a drop of drink - he followed us out of the house, insisted on going home with her, and he gave her a shove.
STEEL's Defence. I am totally innocent.

FOX -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 20.

STEEL -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 29.
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

915.
THOMAS QUINLY
and
CHARLOTTE JONES
were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Steel
, on the 13th of January , and stealing therein 30 sovereigns, one 50l., and one 10l. Bank-note, his property .
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

JAMES STEEL
. I am a fellowship-porter , and live at No. 9. Wellington-street
; at the time in question I lived in Billet-court, and rented the whole house, which had only two rooms. I left home at six o'clock in the morning of the 13th of January, returned at nine in the evening, and missed this property; I went into the bedroom, and found a hole in the ceiling large enough for persons to come through, and the tiles taken off.

ELIZABETH STEEL
. I am the wife of James Steel. On the morning of the 13th of January I went out at eleven o'clock, and at half-past twelve I went up stairs, saw a hole in the ceiling, and the tiles taken off; the mattress was drawn from under the bed, and this money taken out of it; I had felt it there at nine that morning - there were thirty-four sovereigns, a 50l. and 10l. Bank note, which we received, as a compensation for a house, from the Dock Company; I do not know the number of the notes, nor the dates - the mattress was ripped open; I missed nothing else: the male prisoner lived next door, with Jones; I saw Quinly the same day, about two hours after the robbery; he came to his door; I did not speak to him - I was only absent half an hour; the prisoners have been married since the robbery; the man said he worked in a rope-ground - he lived at his mother's house, where I saw him; I have not seen him with any money since.

HANNAH JORDAN
. I am the wife of Richard Jordan, a travelling-musician, and live in Tower-street, Westminster-road. I know the prisoner Jones; I saw her after Christmas - I do not know the month; it was six or seven weeks before I heard of this robbery: she called at my mother's house, where I was, and wanted to know if my mother knew where her father lived, and asked if she bought a few things, if she might leave them there; she gave her permission - I went out with her, and bought a little box and a Britannia metal tea-pot; we came home, and she left us - I saw her again about a week afterwards: she then asked my mother if she might bring her young man in - my mother gave her leave, and she brought the prisoner in- they drank tea at our house; they both called again next morning, and said they wished my mother was well enough to go out and purchase a few things for them; my mother was too ill, and I went: they bought a bedstead, mattress, chairs, wash-hand stand, and several small things, which came to about 4l. 16s.; they took a room next door to my mother's, and the things were sent home: I heard them order them to be sent there. I saw Quinly with four or five sovereigns, and I saw him hold up two notes - he told me they were sailor's notes; my mother said she thought noteswould not go; he said, "Oh, yes, I can get rid of them" -I looked over his shoulder, and saw one with "10" marked on it, and the other with "50;" he took two or three sovereigns out of a small bag - I believe it was all gold; I could not tell how much was in it: they went to another shop, and bought a bed and bedding.
COURT. Q. Did you know what sort of notes they were? A. No, they were too far from me.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. Did he take them out and show them to you? A. No, I stood behind him at a distance - he took them out and held them up.

JANE HEWITT
. I am the wife of Mark Hewitt, and live in Duke-street, Borough. Jones called on me one day after Christmas, when I was ill in bed; I think it was in January - she said she was going to be married to the young man, whose mother she worked with, and asked if I would let her leave some things at my house which she was going to buy; she left a box and a tea-pot - she locked the box, and went away; they both came eight or nine days after, and took some money out of the box - I saw something in their hand, in a little bag, and heard money rattle between them; I saw Quinly with two bits of dirty paper in his hand; he said they were notes - I said that notes did not pass - he said he could make those notes go any where, but they were of no use to any one else; they looked to me like dirty paper, and as he said he had saved his money at sea, I thought he was a sailor - they went to live next door, but moved before they were taken.

CHARLOTTE HEWITT
. I am the daughter of Jane Hewitt. I was present when the prisoner Jones came; it was not long after Christmas; she came to know where her father lived; my mother did not know - my sister went out with her, and they brought home a box; she took the key of the box, and went away.
JAMES STEEL. The notes were clean when I had them - I got them from Barclay's banking-house; I kept my money in a dark short bag.
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury - before Mr. Recorder.

916.
GEORGE COCKLIN
and
SAMUEL GOODWIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , 2 umbrellas, value 10s. , the goods of
John Teesdale
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM WADE
. I am servant to Mr.
John Teesdale
, a solicitor of Fenchurch-street
. There was a stand of umbrellas in the hall; on the morning of the 3d of March, between seven and eight o'clock, I passed through the hall, and the umbrellas were safe; there was a silk and a cotton one - the dustmen were there, taking away the dust as I went out; I came back about a quarter before eight, and the two umbrellas were gone - I have not seen them since.

WILLIAM LONG
. On the morning of the 3d of March I was in Fenchurch-street, about a quarter before eight, o'clock; I have seen the prisoners about the street before that; I know them by sight - on the 3d of March I saw them near Mr. Teesdale's door at a quarter before eight; they were looking at the houses, as if looking for a number- the dust-cart was before the door; they were talking together - Goodwin went into Mr. Teesdale's house; Cocklin looked all about, and then whistled; Goodwin then came out with two umbrellas under his arm - they walked down London-street; I turned back and told the dustman - I saw nothing more of them; London-street would take them to Crutched-friars - I am quite sure they are the two men; I afterwards went up to George-yard, Wentworth-street, to the George public-house, to show the officers where I thought they would be - I saw them there; I did not go in; I saw them standing at the door - I told the officers, who went in and took them - but they were obstinate, and would not go with them; I am quite sure the prisoners are the persons; the officers were obliged to let go of them - a young woman was there, and they sent out a man to call in assistance; I saw them again next day in George-yard, and knew them to be the men - they said nothing to me; they were taken before the Justice about a fortnight afterwards, and I was certain of them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How old are you? A. Thirteen years; the officers could not take them- they forced through the house; I was never taken up for any thing - I gave information; they were followed immediately to their lodgings - no umbrellas were found; I lost sight of them, because I turned round to tell the dustman; one went down London-street, and the other down Mark-lane; that took about five minutes - the public-house is a quarter of a mile off.

Q. Did you tell the officers who the men were? A. I told them where I thought they would be, because I had often seen them about George-yard; I live in George-street - I work for Mr. Smith - I was going over to my grandmother's, in the Borough; I did not follow down London-street: I was never in custody myself.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What is your father? A. A labourer at St Katharine's Docks. I get work where I can- it was three quarters of an hour after that I saw them in George-yard.

JAMES DRURY
. I am a cellar-man to Lee and Bradshaw, of Mineing-lane. On the 3d of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning. I was passing by Mr. Teesdale's door, and saw the two prisoners talking together at the door; I watched them - on my looking at them, Goodwin walked round Mark-lane, and pretended to look at a door opposite for a number; he then came back, spoke to the other, walked into the passage, and came out - I only saw the top of one umbrella; he spoke to Cocklin, and walked round London-street - I went after him with a permit-writer, and near the steps leading to Crutched-friars, I called out "Stop him with the umbrella;" he then began to run, and turned down the steps into Crutched-friars - I ran into the middle of the road, calling out Stop him! I saw Devey running after him; I then left them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see Hewitt? A. No; I was on the other side of the way - I was about twelve yards from the door, when Goodwin went in; there might be another person on the other side of the cart without my seeing him; Goodwin went by the back of the cart, I followed on the opposite; I saw no boy about, but I was noticing the prisoners; I knew Goodwin before - I saw him afterwards at Lambeth-street; I said he was the person - I saw but one umbrella in his hand; when I followed him, he put it down, and held it down - he might have had two.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You saw him near the house,then went across the way, so that the cart was between you? A. Yes; he spoke to the other, and immediately walked into the passage - a whistle could have been given without my hearing it; he walked quietly till I called Stop him! and then ran.

THOMAS DEVEY
. I am street-keeper of Aldgate. On the morning of the 3d of March I was on duty in Crutched-friars, and pursued Goodwin, whom Drury pointed out - he was running with two umbrellas under his arm, one green and the other a dark colour; he turned through Northumberland-alley, ran across Fenchurch-street into Leadenhall-street, and at last got away; I went back afterwards and gave information - I afterwards went to Mr. Teesdale's house and saw Long; I went with him to George-yard - both the prisoners were drinking at the bar; I went and seized Goodwin by the collar, and told him he had committed the robbery; the patrol seized Cocklin - a dreadful struggle ensued: they called for assistance from a person, I think, named White - there were four or five at the bar; I pulled Goodwin out of the house, the patrol had got Cocklin inside, and they were all upon him - I went to his assistance, and they all retreated out of the back door - I went to Lambeth-street Office and gave information.
Cross-examined. Q. He had no umbrella at the public-house? A. No.

WILLIAM ARTHUR
. I am inspector of the watch. I accompanied Devey to the George, George-yard - Long said, "There they are;" Devey took hold of Goodwin and I of Cocklin - he screamed out that I was going to grab him, which means to take him; a woman came to his assistance, and threw herself between us; he broke from me, and ran through the back door of the house - I followed him - three people came to his assistance and rescued him from me a second time; I lost him, and did not see him again till the 17th of March; I knew him again.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You seized him without saying a word? A. I had my staff in my hand, and said, "I wanted him;" he called out that I was going to grab him; that could be heard outside the house; I did not know Long before, and never knew any thing against him.

THOMAS SHELLSWELL
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. On the 11th of March I went to a lodging-house in Wentworth-street, and found the two prisoners in the same room; I told them I came to apprehend them for a crack down the road - that means housebreaking; Cocklin said, "If that I the case we will go with you quietly; but if it is for the City job we are sure to be lugged;" which means transported - they went quietly.

Cross-examined. Q. A crack means breaking open a house, not going into an open door? A. No; it means a regular burglary: I did not take them at their regular lodgings, they were out of the way; I knew their lodgings, and searched them, but found nothing.

JURY to LONG. Q. Did you know any thing of the prisoners before to induce you to watch them? A. No; I watched them because I thought they were after no good; I had seen them about; they had been pointed out to me; I knew they lived in Cage-street, Wentworth-street.
GOODWIN'S Defence. I went up to Cocklin's house, and had not been there five minutes before Shellswell came in.
COCKLIN's Defence. I never was there.

COCKLIN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

GOODWIN -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

917.
SARAH BOWICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of February , at St. Botolph Without, Aldgate, 1 watch, value 10l.; 1 watch-chain, value 5l.; 2 seals, value 20s.; 2 rings, value 15s.; 1 watch-key, value 10s.; 1 box, value 5s.; and 1 slide, value 15s., the goods of
James Muirhead
, in the dwelling-house of
John Little
.

HANNAH MUIRHEAD. I am the wife of
James Muirhead
- we live at the Crown and Magpie tavern
- it is my father's house - his name is
John Little
- it is in the parish of St. Botolph, Aldgate, and in the City
. The prisoner was servant in the house, and had been so about ten days or a fortnight at the time of the robbery - there was one more servant in the house besides her; I lost a gold watch, with a chain to it - it was locked up in my bed-room, and had two seals, two rings, one key, a box and slide - they were all locked in my bed-room, which is one of the rooms detached from the house, but part of the dwelling-house; the prisoner used to clean the room, and attend to it; I know the property was safe the day before I missed it - I saw it all, it was locked in a drawer - I put the key into another drawer, which was not locked; I missed it next day, and made inquiry about it, and the prisoner helped me to look for it - but it was not found; I saw the watch at Lambeth-street office, and the chain, but it was not then attached to the watch; when I lost it, the watch-chain, seals, a ring, key, and slide, were all fastened together, and put in a red morocco case - I saw it at Lambeth-street about a month after I missed it, which was on the 2d of February; my father rented the house - my husband was at sea.

WILLIAM BROCK
. I am shopman to Nicholls and Latter, pawnbrokers, No. 80, Broad-street, Ratcliff-cross. I took a gold chain in pawn on the 16th of February for 24s. of the prisoner - I am certain she is the person - she never pawned there before; she was about a quarter of an hour with me - I am quite certain of her person: the prisoner said the chain belonged to a Mrs. Page, for whom she pawned it, and her own name was
Sarah Bowick
, No. 2, Webb's-place, which is in Limehouse; I produced it at the office about a fortnight after - Mrs. Muirhead claimed it.
MRS. MUIRHEAD. This is my chain - I had had it about three months - I am positive of it.

HENRY HAWKINS
. I am a pawnbroker, of Catherine-street, Limehouse. I bought a seal of the prisoner on the 16th or 17th of February; I am certain of her - she gave me her own name; she said it was given her by a former sweetheart, and having married another person, she did not want it; the officer has it - this is it (looking at it) - I gave it to the officer - I gave 8s. for it.
MRS. MUIRHEAD. I know this seal - it is exactly like mine - it is an amethyst seal, and no engraving on it; the prisoner left the service exactly a fortnight after I lost it.

EDWARD WILLIAM
WIGGINS. I am servant to Mr. Dicker, a pawnbroker, of Three Colt-street, Limehouse. I have a gold watch, pawned on the 21st of February, by the prisoner, in the name of Sarah Page; she said shepawned it for her mother; I am quite sure of her person- I have seen her in the neighbourhood before - she was about twenty minutes with me; I advanced 4l. on it; it was produced at the office on the 3d of March, and claimed by Mrs. Muirhead.
MRS. MUIRHEAD. I am certain it is mine - my husband has no other Christian name; I have been married about twelve months; I had had the watch about three months - and am certain of it.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. I apprehended the prisoner first on the 23d of February, in the room of Mrs. Higgins, a witness who is not here; I told her it was on suspicion of stealing a gold watch; she denied all knowledge of it; in coming down stairs she whipped very quick into the first floor room - I went to look for her, and found her behind the door; I found nothing on her; I took her to the office, and she was discharged: about four days after, Mrs. Little, Mrs. Muirhead's mother, brought her to the office in a coach; I then went round to the different pawnbrokers - I searched her, but found no duplicates on her; I have a seal, pawned in Ratcliff-highway; I have also a slide, ring, and key, which were found by the witness who is not here.
MRS. MUIRHEAD. This is one of my seals; this slide, key, and ring were all attached to my watch - I know them by the pattern; I went after the prisoner's character, and was satisfied with it.

JOHN LITTLE
. I keep this tavern, and rent the whole premises; my daughter slept in a room within the premises - it was part of the dwelling-house that I rented - it was all rated as one house - my daughter paid me no rent - I could turn her out of the room whenever I pleased.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 22.
Recommended to mercy by the prosecutrix, believing it to be her first offence, and on account of her youth .

918.
THOMAS DANIELS
and
CAROLINE KENSETT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 5 handkerchiefs, value 8s. 9d. , the goods of
John Woolmer
.

THOMAS WARWICK
. I am a shopman to
John Woolmer
, a linen-draper and haberdasher , of Barbican
. These handkerchiefs were all in one piece - about the 5th of March I had been showing some to a gentleman, and this one among them - I saw them safe a quarter of an hour before - the prisoners came into the shop together to look at some cotton handkerchief, which were in a different part of the shop, within reach of these handkerchiefs - they were on the counter; they left the shop without buying; I did not miss the handkerchiefs till an officer gave me information; he had taken the prisoners, and produced the handkerchiefs, with my own mark on them.

GEORGE BULLEN
. I am a coach-maker. I was near Woolmer's shop, about seven o'clock in the evening; I first saw a lad looking in at the window - in a few minutes after, the prisoners came up and joined him - they stood at the window about ten minutes; the lad went into the shop first, and the prisoners followed him; I saw them looking at the cotton handkerchiefs, and then went to the end of the shop - I saw them all three come out together; they turned up Golden-lane, which is about two doors from the shop - a waggon passed, and I called to Vann, the officer, to follow them; they walked very fast- I ran to keep them in sight; I never lost sight of them; they turned up Playhouse-yard; the lad and the female went up the court, and the man stood at the corner - they returned down again, and Vann took bold of the woman; I took the man, the boy ran away; Vann said to the woman "What have you here?" she said Nothing, and he took the piece of handkerchiefs from under her shawl: it was claimed by Warwick - they were searched, and 3 1/2d. found on them together.

JOHN VANN
. I had been watching the prisoners for half an hour, and saw them go into the shop and come out - I laid hold of the female at the end of the court; the lad went away - I did not observe him with them at that time; seeing the woman's bosom bulky, I put my hand under her shawl and found the handkerchiefs; she said she had picked them up on the pavement - she had 3 1/2d.; Daniels had no money.(Property produced and sworn to.)
KENSETT's Defence. The other prisoner is innocent.
DANIELS' Defence. I know nothing about the concern; when I came out of the shop I was going home, and did not positively know any thing was taken.

DANIELS -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

KENSETT -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

919.
HENRY JOHNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
John White Welch
, from his person .

JOHN WHITE WELCH
. I am clerk to a merchant , and live at Camberwell. On the 17th of March, about ten o'clock in the morning, I was in Gracechurch-street
; I had come from Camberwell, and had a yellow silk handkerchief in my pocket - I felt my coat move, instantly turned round, and observed the prisoner, and a young man in company with him; I laid hold of the prisoner by the hand, in which I found my handkerchief - he was in the act of putting it under his coat: a gentleman who was with me seized his companion - we took them both to the Mansion-house; the prisoner said he had picked it up, but I felt it go from my pocket, turned round, and caught it in his hand - his companion was discharged - I have not seen him since; the handkerchief had my name on it in full length, and the name of my cousin, which was marked on it as well, by mistake.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you taken the handkerchief out shortly before? A. Not that I recollect; I felt it go out of my pocket, which made me turn round - he said he had picked it up; I saw nobody run away.

JAMES BOOTH
. I was with Mr. Welch, in Gracechurch-street; he turned round very sharp, and I turned round and caught the prisoner's hand in his own breastpocket with the handkerchief, trying to hide it there - I laid hold of the other.

THOMAS HERDSFIELD
. I am a constable. The prisoner was delivered into my charge at the Mansion-house.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the one who hasbeen released? A. Yes; he is a notorious character, and older than the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to the Borough to look for work; this gentleman's handkerchief was on the ground; I immediately stooped to pick it up, and put it into my pocket - he turned round and I offered it to him; he took me to the Mansion-house; the other man, who was a stranger to me, has been convicted three times.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .
NEW COURT, Sixth Day.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

920.
PATRICK CALLAGHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 3lbs. weight of pork, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Gammage
.

WILLIAM GAMMAGE
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Drury-lane
. On the 1st of April, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, the witness gave me information, and I missed this pork; I had seen it safe within half an hour, in my window, which was open.

WILLIAM MACKEY
. I saw the prisoner stand at the window, and take out this pork; I gave an alarm, and Deverell went and took him with it - he did not seem so drunk when he took it, as when he was brought back.

WILLIAM DEVERELL
. Mackey gave an alarm; I pursursued and took the prisoner; he directly offered to pay for the pork - it was then lying very near him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in liquor.
GUILTY . Aged 37.
Confined One Month .

921.
ADOLPHUS DICKSON
,
EDWARD BROWN
, and
CHARLES BRYANT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 2 shirts, value 10s.; 3 collars, value 1s. 6d., and 1 stock, value 6d. , the goods of
John Eates
.

ELIZA EATES
. I am the wife of
John Eates
. I went, on the 24th of March, from a lady's, in Baker-street, to whom these things belonged, to my mother's, in Bagnigge-wells-road
; I left these articles there, tied up in a white handkerchief, by the side of the counter - I went out for about five minutes, and they were then gone; these are the things; here are two shirts, three collars, and one stock.

ELIZABETH EATES
. I am Eates' mother-in-law. She left a bundle at my shop on the 24th of March; she went out; Brown and Bryant came in, asked for half a pint of beer, and change for a shilling; I gave them the change - while I stooped to draw the beer, they were gone, and the bundle likewise; I knew Dickson, but I did not see him at that time - he was about the door, I believe, but I did not exactly notice; Dickson was not in the shop.

WILLIAM ROBERTS
. I am a constable. I took Dickson on the 24th of March, about half-past nine o'clock at night: I asked if he knew any thing about a robbery of some linen; he said No; I told him to get up, and go with me - he then said the things should be forthcoming in the morning; I asked where they were; he said at Mr. Button's; I asked where the tickets were; he said they did not give any; I locked him up, went back, and found this shirt under the head of his bed.

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEPHENS
. I took up Brown and Bryant- they denied all knowledge of the things.

EDWARD HADDAWAY
. Dickson desired me one night to pawn a shirt, a stock, a handkerchief, and a collar - I do not know when it was; I pawned them at Mr. Button's - they were in a bundle; I was desired to sell the ticket; and went to do so, but it was stopped.

JOHN BUTTON
. I am servant to
Daniel Button
, a pawnbroker. On the 24th of March I received these articles from Haddaway.

HENRY DEYEN
. On the 24th of March I was at the back of the field, and saw Dickson run in a contrary way from the prosecutor's shop, with a bundle; he was on the other side of the bridge, a good step from the shop.
Dickson put in a written defence, stating that he had found the property in question. He received a good character.

DICKSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

BRYANT -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

922.
HENRY HENDERSON
and
EDWARD FITZGERALD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 copper warming-pan, value 14s. , the goods of
Robert William Whitfield
.

ROBERT WILLIAM WHITFIELD
. I lost a copper warming-pan from my shop-door, in Oxford-street
, about ten o'clock on the morning of the 14th of March; I took the prisoners with it: Henderson took it, and gave it to Fitzgerald.

JAMES CONDIE
. I am an officer. I received the prisoners in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
HENDERSON'S Defence. I was coming from Hyde-park, and saw Fitzgerald standing at the corner of North Audley-street; a gentleman asked me to hold a horse - I know nothing of the pan.

FITZGERALD's Defence. I stopped at the corner of North Audley-street, and a gentleman came and asked this prisoner to hold his horse; I saw this pan, and took it up - the gentleman came out of the shop, and took us.

HENDERSON -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

FITZGERALD -
NOT GUILTY .

923.
WILLIAM HOGG
and
WILLIAM BANKS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 1 rug, value 6s., and 1 umbrella, value 2s. , the goods of the Honourable
Richard Hobart Fitzgibbon
.

ELIJAH ASHLEY
. I am a hackney-coach proprietor. I was in Sloane-street, New-road, on the 18th of March, about a quarter-past nine o'clock; I then went to the Haymarket
; I there saw Banks, who is a hackney-coachman - Hogg was with him; I saw Hogg take a rug from a gentleman's carriage, which was going by empty towards the House of Commons, and put it into Bank's coach, who was feeding his horses at the time; I do not know whether Bank saw it.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Does not Banks keep a coach of his own? A. Yes.

HENRY HOWLETT
. I am a watchman. I was on dutyon the evening of the 18th of March; Ashley gave me information, and I took Hogg - I then opened Banks' carriage, and took this rug and umbrella out; Banks said he knew nothing of them, or of Hogg.

HENRY WILLIAMS
. I am a patrol. I assisted in taking Hogg - I saw Howlett take these things from the chariot; Hogg attempted to escape from me - I said if he did I would draw my sword; Banks said he knew nothing of them, or of the prisoner, but he said afterwards that he lived next door to him - Colonel Fitzgibbon's servant swore to these things, but he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

924.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of March , 1 silk umbrella, value 18s. , the goods of
Francis Moor
.

EDWARD WILLSON
. I am shopman to Mr. Francis Moor, of St. Martin's-court
. On the 9th of March I missed an umbrella from the shop, which I had seen not long before; the officer brought in the prisoner with it.

JOHN GROOM
. I am an officer. On the 9th of March, about nine o'clock in the evening. I observed the prisoner and another lad loitering about this shop; I watched them, and saw the prisoner take something from his pocket - he immediately stepped into the shop, and brought out this umbrella; he came down the court with the other -I tripped up the heels of the other, and took the prisoner with this umbrella and knife.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home - I saw the umbrella lay, and took it.

JOHN GROOM
. There was no dirt on it; I saw him reach into the shop, as if to cut a string.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

925.
CATHERINE KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , 6 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Benjamin Sowerby
.

JOB VALENTINE WATKINS
. I am in the employ of Mr.
Thomas Benjamin Sowerby
, pawnbroker , of Chiswell-street
. On the 3d of April, the prisoner came in, and went to the pledge side; I suspected her, and saw her roll something up and go out - I followed her, and found this cotton under her arm; I had seen it while she was in the shop.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Are you sure it is your master's? A. Yes.

JOHN BROWN
. I took the prisoner; I found upwards of eighty duplicates on her - half of them were for linen and cotton.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Two Months .

926.
DAVID LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
Samuel Swoolston
.

JOSEPH HOTCHKISS
. I am shopman to Mr.
Samuel Swoolston
, a boot-maker . On the 14th of March a young man told me these boots were gone, and I missed them from the nail I had seen them on but a few minutes before, when I was at the door - I went across; I saw the prisoner at the length of the street, but could not go after him - they have not been found.

JOSEPH CHURCH
. I was coming past the door at a quarter after ten o'clock in the morning; I saw the prisoner stoop and creep under the front of the window - he put his hand and took the boots off a nail in the shop; he ran into High-street, Bloomsbury - I went to the house where he delivered them, and should have had them, but there were so many ruffians about; I swear I saw him take them - he ran to what is called Rats' Castle.

THOMAS PLUME
. I took the prisoner on the 14th of March - I found nothing on him; he said the boots were in Rats' Castle, but said another boy took them.

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking past the shop - another boy stooped and took the boots; the gentleman knocked me right under the horse's feet - they afterwards came and took me: I said I knew nothing about them -I ran home; they came again and took me.

JOSEPH CHURCH
. There was no other boy with him, nor any one near enough to take them but him; I could not catch him, he ran so fast.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

927.
GEORGE OAKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of March , 6 lbs. weight of pork, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Seth Barber
.

SETH BARBER
I am a cheesemonger , and live in Baldwin's-gardens
. On the 21st of March I heard a call of Stop thief! and ran out; Flemming brought the prisoner and this pork in - I knew it to be mine, and had seen it about ten minutes before.

JOHN FLEMMING
. On that evening, between eight and nine o'clock, I was passing the prosecutor's shop; I saw the prisoner snatch the piece of pork, put it in his apron, and run off - I pursued; he was stopped in Kirby-street, Hatton-garden - I am quite sure he is the person.

JOSEPH COGGER
. I am a publican. I found this piece of pork in my passage, which is about one hundred yards from the prosecutor's; I did not see who put it there - several persons ran by the house.

MATTHIAS WELDHEN
. I am an officer. I heard a cry of Stop thief! I saw a person run from the prosecutor's shop, across Leather-lane; I secured him in Kirby-street- I did not see at first who it was; the prisoner said he did it, because he was in distress, and had nothing to eat.
GUILTY. Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Fourteen Days .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

928.
WILLIAM POPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 1 counterpane, value 12s.; 1 pair of blankets, value 20s.; 1 sheet, value 6s.; 1 pillow, value 7s., and 1 bolster, value 10s. , the goods of
William Leach
.

ELIZABETH LEACH
. I am the wife of
William Leach
; we live in Zion-terrace
, and let a furnished lodging to the prisoner on the 18th of February by the week; all the articles stated were in the room, as part of the furniture - he went away on the 20th without giving notice, and these articles were missing; we have not found any of them - he was taken in about a month.

THOMAS BINFORD KERSWELL
. I am an officer. Leach gave me a description of the prisoner, and I took him in St. James'-park.
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

929
LYDIA SHEPHERD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 1 sovereign and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Thomas John Freeman
, from his person .

THOMAS JOHN FREEMAN
. I keep a coal-shed in New Gravel-lane. On the 16th of March I was at the Ship and Unicorn public-house in New Gravel-lane
- I found the prisoner there; it was between one and two o'clock - I was sober; there were but a couple of pots of beer between four or five of us - the prisoner lived within two doors of me; I have sold her coals, and when I went in she said, "What, are you come you old b-r?" I said,"You had better use better words and pay me for my coals;" for she owed me 8d. - she said, "I will have your life before I will pay you;" as I was sitting against the window they put some flour all over my clothes, and threw some in my eyes, then threw me backwards, throttled, and robbed me of a sovereign and a sixpence - the prisoner was kneeling on my breast, and was choking me; I felt her hand in my pocket - I could not call out, because she strangled me; there were a good many persons there in the same line - she keeps a bad house; there were two or three men there - they went and told my wife, who came, caught hold of her, and broke her hold: I did not go to tell any officer - next morning my eyes were so bad that I could not get up; before I got better she went and got a warrant for me, and when I told my tale they committed her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many people were in the room when she choked and robbed you? A. Five, six or seven - there was not a single man besides myself; two men went and told my wife, but they did not see any part of the row - after they went out of the house I did not knock the prisoner down, I am sure; I could not go that night to an officer or a Magistrate - I could not see out of my eyes; I did keep a house, but I had left it that day - I have had two lodgers, but I never took in lodgers by the hour, nor by the day; I have by the week, never by the night - I have been six or seven months in the potatoe business; I cannot tell whether I called for a glass of gin in the house - I never drank one; if I had asked for ten glasses of gin I could have had them - I have understood the prisoner's husband has died since this happened.

SARAH GINGLE
. I went to the house, saw the prosecutor on the floor, and the prisoner on his breast - she had her right hand in his right-hand waistcoat pocket, and said"You old b-r, before I have done, I will have your life;" I came out directly - I saw there was white-wash or colour on his back, and all about him; I afterwards saw his wife take him home.

Cross-examined. Q. Is not the prosecutor your father? A. Yes; the report was given by the fiddler and plasterer- I ran over; I did not notice my father's eyes - I did not see him for two or three days afterwards.
NOT GUILTY .

930.
CHARLES LEDGERWOOD
and
ABEL SAMELLS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 1 bushel of coals, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Job Cook
.

JOB COOK
. I am in the coal trade , and live at Hammersmith
. On the 19th of February, a barge had come in with twenty-one chaldron of coals, about five o'clock in the afternoon; I sent a person to watch it, as it was to remain at the wharf all night.

WILLIAM HEDGES
. I was sent to watch the barge: I was playing with a white dog between seven and eight o'clock, and saw the two prisoners come on the barge; I told them they had better get off, or it would be worse for them: they would not - but they threw down the coals to two others, and they ran off with them - I ran after them; Ledgerwood dropped his piece of coal - the others got away with theirs; I knew the two prisoners before.
Prisoner SAMELLS. He said he never saw me before - but a bricklayer's boy told him it was me. Witness. I know him very well, and knew him at the time.

JAMES SMITH
. I am a constable. I took up the prisoners, and accused them of stealing the coals - and as I was bringing them to town, they acknowledged taking a few; they were very nearly rescued from me.

LEDGERWOOD's Defence. He took my brother - I went to the cage to see him, and this boy swore to me - the officer then came and said, "I want you for the coals;" I walked with him - he had no trouble with me.
SAMELL's Defence. We have had seven weeks in Clerkenwell prison - and, if we were guilty, I think it is quite punishment enough - I know no more of them than a new-born baby.

LEDGERWOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

SAMELLS -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.

931.
WILLIAM SAUNDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , 2 pairs of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Robert George Brodie
.

ROBERT GEORGE BRODIE
. I am a ladies' shoemaker . and live in Cranbourn-passage
. About a quarter after three o'clock, on the 6th of April, I was going over the way to a person who conducted my business during my illness, and the prisoner took these shoes from the corner bar, but I did not see him; they have not been found.

JOSEPH BURKE
. I live on the first floor of a house opposite the prosecutor's. About a quarter past three o'clock on the 6th of April, I was looking through my window, and saw the prisoner looking in the prosecutor's window - he went to the door, and unhooked the two pairs of shoes - before I could open the window he was gone; I went down, and saw the prosecutor; we went to Castle-street, and saw the prisoner loitering about, as if he was coming back again; I do not know what became of the shoes; I am sure that he is the lad - he was taken in three or four minutes.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

932.
MARY TOOLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 2 tongues, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Sculling
.

SARAH KENDRICK
. On the 7th of March I was at the shop of Mr.
John Sculling
, a cheesemonger ; the prisoner came in, and called for a quarter of a lb. of butter - shepaid 2d. for it: she went to the tub, and took out one tongue - she turned again, and put another in her apron; she was going out, and the lad asked if she had paid for them; she made no answer, but struck him, and struck me, and tore my bonnet off; the watchman was called, and took her.

ARTHUR POWER
. I serve in the shop; I saw the two tongues in the prisoner's apron - to the best of my knowledge she had not bought them; she struck me because I stopped her; there was a shopman serving.

JOHN SCULLING
. These tongues were mine; I was outside the window; when I took hold of the prisoner, she fell down - I left her. while I got the watchman.

WILLIAM HORNSBY
