. I am the watchman. I took the prisoner - she was in liquor, but seemed to know what she was about, and was capable of walking.

Prisoner's Defence. I had bought the tongues, and then went with a friend and had something to drink; as I was going home, I called for some butter, and was going to take the tongues, for which I had paid the shopman.
GUILTY. Aged 23.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Six Weeks .

933.
THOMAS WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 8 birds, value 20s. , the goods of
Edward Wigley
.

No evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

923.
THOMAS WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 1 looking-glass, value 16s. , the goods of
William Smith
.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I live in York-street, Westminster
. I lost this glass on Saturday evening, the 11th of April, about ten minutes before seven o'clock; it had been about four feet inside the front of my shop.

THOMAS TRENT
. I am in the Coldstream Guards. I saw the prisoner reach into the shop and take this glass - I took him and brought him back - there was another young man with him who threw a sack over the glass when the prisoner put it down on the stones.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Pimlico and was returning - the witness came and said I had stolen the glass, but I had not seen it.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

934.
JONAS SIMONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 1 crown, and 1 half-crown , the monies of
William Arnold Hadden Hows
.

JOHN COOK
. I am foreman to Mr. Hows, a pawnbroker , of High-street, St. Giles'
. On the 17th of February the prisoner came into one of the private boxes, and asked the shopman to give him a sovereign for a pounds worth of silver; the shopman is not here; I saw him give him the sovereign - he did not seem satisfied, and said, as well as he could speak in broken English, that he wanted it changed for two half-sovereigns; he gave him the two half-sovereigns and then he did not seem satisfied, but wanted one of the half-sovereigns changed for silver; the shopman pulled out the till to do so; the till had been out before - it was just under the counter, opposite the private boxes; he then put the half-sovereign on the counter, put his hand into the till, and said in broken English, how easily any body might help themselves; I saw him draw his hand from the till, and put it down by the side of his trousers pocket; he then took his hand from his side, and put it into the till a second time; I had not seen him put any thing into his pocket, but he was saying something which we could not understand; I watched him more sharply - I was standing on his right-hand side, and saw between his thumb and the palm of his right hand a crown-piece, two half-crowns, and some other silver, which he drew from the till, and put into his right-hand breeches pocket; the shopman and I together accused him of it - he said something that we could not understand, and shifted his hand from his breeches pocket to the side pocket of his coat, or to that part of his person - his hand was under his coat on his left side: Mr. Hows sent for an officer and had him taken - this half-sovereign and the 10s. were laid on the counter during the scuffle.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Have you always given the same account of this? A. Yes; I did not state the prisoner asked us to give him change for a sovereign; he wanted a sovereign for silver; he spoke English very imperfectly - we had some difficulty in understanding what he wanted; he pointed to the drawer, that he wanted 10s. for a half-sovereign; I saw the two half-crowns and the crown in his hand, and some more silver; I swear I saw shillings and sixpences in his hand - there were, I suppose, 5l., 6l., or 7l. in the till - it was not so very large; a female was on the same side of the counter as he was - he could see her if he looked round; she is not here, she has left her lodgings; the prisoner made great resistance; Mr. Hows jumped over the counter and seized him, and they were scuffling when I left; he put his hand across to show what sort of silver he wanted - the counter is about four feet high, and about two feet and a half wide - and the till was opposite him.

THOMAS WRIGHT
. I was sent for, and found the prisoner and Mr. Hows scuffling together; I took the prisoner into the back parlour, and from his left-hand waistcoat pocket I took 2l. 13s. in silver - there was one crownpiece, six half-crowns, and shillings and sixpences; I began to feel at his trousers pocket, and from his left-hand, trousers pocket he drew a purse which contained money -I took it to Marlborough street, where Mr. Plank opened it - it contained thirty-six sovereigns and a half; I do not know why the woman is not here; I went to her lodgings several times, and last Saturday the landlady told me that a Jewess had been there and given her money.
Cross-examined. Q. Had not the prisoner a pack of goods near him? A. Yes, he had: I did not search his coat pockets till we got to Marlborough-street.

WILLIAM ARNOLD HADDEN HOWS
. I am the owner of the shop. The prisoner wade great resistance, and wished to get away.
Cross-examined. Q. He is a foreigner - did you explain to him the object you had in view? A. I did not.
Prisoner's Defence. (Through an interpreter.) I am innocent; I did not want any thing of the kind - I had plenty of money.
NOT GUILTY .

934.
JOHN RAWLINS
and
MARY ANN HAYTER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March
, 2 sheets, value 5s.; 1 clock, value 10s.; 1 pair of bellows, value 1s.; 1 counterpane, value 5s.; 1 candlestick, value 6d.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; 1 looking-glass, value 2s. 6d., and 1 flatiron, value 6d. , the goods of
Richard Lowe
.

HAYTER
pleaded GUILTY .

RICHARD LOWE
. I live at No. 74, Turnmill-street
. I let a lodging to the prisoners on the 23d or 24th of February - they left on the 14th of March without notice; I got into the room and missed the property stated; I had let them both out on the Saturday night with a bundle and a basket.

DANIEL PAINTER
. I am an officer. I apprehended Hayter - the property has not been found.
RAWLINS' Defence. I know nothing of the robbery - this woman knows so; I took nothing out of the room.

RAWLINS -
GUILTY . Aged 36.

936.
JOHN RAWLINS
and
MARY ANN HAYTER
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March
, 1 bed, value 2l.; 1 looking-glass, value 8s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 2 sheets, value 2s.; 1 counterpane, value 2s.; 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 candlestick, value 1s.: 4 prints, framed, value 3s.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 2 brass weights, value 2s., and 2 window-curtains, value 1s. , the goods of
William Clarke
.

HAYTER
pleaded GUILTY .

ELIZABETH CLARK
. I am the wife of
William Clark
: we live in Great Sutton-street
. Hayter came and took my lodging on the 25th of March - she asked if I would let her husband look at it; Rawlins stood opposite: she beckoned him up - he said, "My dear, do you like the room?" she said, "Yes - it is 4s. 6d. if I find sheets and 5s. if I don't;" they came in the same night, and were there all the week; they went in and out several times -Hayter came on the Saturday evening, about six o'clock, and said, "Is my husband here?" I said No; she said,"What a lucky house your's is - my husband has met with a person who paid him half a sovereign, and I am to have another presently, and will pay you;" the articles stated were my property, and are all lost.
Prisoner RAWLINS. Q. Do you say I was present looking at the lodging? A. Yes; I have heard you there as late as half-past ten o'clock - I never saw you go out with a bundle.

DANIEL PAINTER
. I took the prisoners; these few feathers were left in the room.
RAWLINS' Defence. I know nothing at all of the property going any more than you do, who are about to sentence me.

RAWLINS -
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence .
There was another indictment against the prisoners, which was not tried.

937.
JOHN KEMP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 1 pair of shoes, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Thomas Lands
.

EDWARD THOMAS LANDS
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Hackney-road
. I know these things to be mine; the prisoner worked seven or eight months for me, and had the care of my shop, which was robbed - we suspected him, and had him taken; the duplicate of these shoes was found on him: I have lost a great deal of property; he had the key of the shop, and slept there.

JAMES HILL
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house, and I found on him the duplicate of a pair of shoes.

WILLIAM CAWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Hackney-road. On the 20th of February I took in these shoes, and gave this duplicate for them - I do not know to whom.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had pledged the shoes to purchase necessary articles for the business.
MR. LANDS. That is not true.
GUILTY. Aged 24.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Three Months .

938.
GEORGE LAWRENCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , 1 hat, value 20s. , the goods of
Charles Best
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

939.
GEORGE DELASEAR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 4 wheels, value 20s. , the goods of
William Leaf
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

940.
HENRY COCKSEDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of March , 1 coat, value 1l.; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Jonathan Cocksedge
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

941.
HENRY BACON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 68lbs. weight of leaden pipe, value 10s., and 1 fixture, (i.e.) 1 brass cock, value 6d., the goods of
Samuel Rivett
, and fixed to a certain building of his .

WILLIAM SAXTON
. I am a mattress-maker. I know the building of Mr. Rivett - it is No. 19, Wellington-street, Kingsland-road
; it is a finished house, but not occupied. On the morning of the 5th of April, at a quarter-past two o'clock, I was going to bed, and heard an alarm; I opened my window, looked out, and an opposite neighbour said there were thieves in the next house - I went down, and heard the bolt of the parlour window drawn; three or four men came out of the house - I closely pursued the prisoner, who was one, and held him till the watchman came.

Prisoner. I was behind him all the way down the street; I never was in the window at all - I could not jump out. Witness. No, you were before me; I never lost sight of you - I said, "You are one of the party," and you said, "I am not."

JOSEPH ARNOLD
. I am a watchman. The witness gave the prisoner to me; I went to the house after we came from the watch-house, and found this piece of pipe and a brass cock - they appeared to have been just cut off.

THOMAS FRANKLIN
. I am a watchman. I went to the house, and found this pipe lying in the passage.

SAMUEL RIVETT
. The house belongs to me, and was not occupied; I had not been there for four or five months - I had left the key next door, but the water came in on the Saturday, and it could not without this pipe; they could not have water till the pipe was put on again - the officer told me of this, and I went on the Sunday; the lead appeared fresh cut.

CHARLES WALLER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I went to the house, and found this pipe and cock; the lead is fresh cut, and part of it was lying near the main-pipe in the kitchen.

JOHN CRICK
. I live next door to the house where the lead was cut. This spoon, which was found on the prisoner, is my property - it was in my back premises; they got over the wall to cut the pipe off; the key was left at No. 20, and the pipe was cut from there and No. 19.

Prisoner's Defence (written.) I was returning home, and passing by Wellington-street, I heard the cry of Stop thief! I went down to see what was the matter, and when I had got about half way down the street, I kicked something before me; I took it up, and found it was a spoon - I put it into my pocket, and followed after them; when I had got to the top of the street, on turning round the corner, I slipped down - the witness turned round, and laid hold of me.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

942.
EDWARD BUTLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of April , 6 half-crowns, 7 shillings 3 sixpences, and 9d. in copper, the monies of
Francis Macnamara
, from his person .

WILLIAM LEWIS
. I was at the White Lion public-house, in St. Giles'
, on the evening of the 2d of April; the prisoner and prosecutor came in together - the prosecutor was very tipsy; I saw the prisoner put his hand into the prosecutor's left-hand pocket, and take out the money- it was in a bit of paper; he gave out 1s. to pay for the beer - he kept the money in his hand some time, and then put it into his own pocket; there were five or six people in the same box; there was no concealment - he got up, went into the yard, and came back; I told him if he did not give him the money I would fetch an officer - he told me not to trouble my head about it; I went for the officer, and the money was found on him: he was not so drunk as the prosecutor - he had been drinking.

FRANCIS MACNAMARA
. I am a Chelsea pensioner . I had been with the prisoner, and we had each got our pensious; I got drunk, and do not know what happened.
NOT GUILTY .

943.
ROBERT BURN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Parton
, from his person .

JOHN PARTON
. I am an attorney . I was in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square
, on the 3d of April, and was informed the prisoner had picked my pocket; I pursued him to a court in Goodge-street, and found my handkerchief on him - I took him to the office, and he was committed.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

944.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 1 wooden till, value 1s.; 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 17 penny-pieces, and 28 halfpence , the property of
Adam Mott
.

HANNAH MOTT
. I am sister of
Adam Mott
, who lives in George-street, Euston-square
. About four o'clock in the afternoon of the 16th of March, I was in the parlour, adjoining the shop, which is a grocer's; I heard what I thought was a knocking on the counter, but it proved to be the unlocking of the till; I looked, the till was gone, and I saw a person going out of the shop with it, under his arm - I believe the prisoner to be the man; I ran to the door, but he was out of sight; I saw him again in about three hours, at Marlborough-street; this is the till - there was about 8s. 3 1/2d, in it; a person could reach over the counter, and get it.

WILLIAM HAWKINS
. I am an officer. On the 16th of March I was standing at my own house; the prisoner ran by with this till, and the money rattling in it; it was just after four o'clock; he was about four hundred yards from the prosecutor's - I pursued him down a mews; he threw the till into an area, at the corner of Euston-square and Drummond-street, and most of the money went into another area; I took him about one hundred yards further, without losing sight of him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was never inside the shop, and know nothing of it; I was going to a gentleman of the name of Clarkson, second mate of the Repulse; a man came behind me, and threw this till into the area - there was a cry of Stop thief! I ran after the man, and this gentleman took me.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

945.
ROBERT CARTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 1 goat, price 10s. , the property of
Randall Edward Brewin
.

DANIEL GILES
. I am a bird-fancier. This goat was on Mr. Chapman's premises, at the back of Barnsbury-park. Islington
, on the 11th of April; there is a bank round the field; the prisoner ran, took a strap from his pocket, and led the goat away - he took it into Maiden-lane, and the officer took him; I had not known him before.

WILLIAM BERNARD
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner leading the goat along; I asked him where he was going; he said, home; I asked him where that was; he said somewhere about Holborn; I took the goat to the officer, and gave information.

WILLIAM DOOBER
. I am servant to Mr.
Randall Edward Brewin
. The officer showed me a goat, which I knew was my master's - I know nothing of the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I went after a situation at a varnish-maker's, in Liverpool-road; I was to go on Saturday for an answer - I thought I would go and cut two turfs; a man in the field asked who the goat belonged to; some men said they did not know; he then asked me if I would earn sixpence or a shilling, and take the goat with him - he called the goat, and it came; he took hold of it, put a string round it, and told me to lead it - he walked on, and went away.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

946.
THOMAS CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 pair of breeches, value 4s., and 1 scarf, value 2s. , the goods of
James Chapman Butcher
.

WILLIAM HARRISON
. I am assistant to
James Chapman Butcher
, pawnbroker , of New Brentford
. We lost this scarf and pair of breeches, on the 7th of April, from inside the shop door; I had seen the prisoner in the town.

JOHN COPE FOLKARD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Old Brentford. About half-past eight o'clock on this evening this pair of breeches was brought to me by the prisoner; he wanted five shillings on them - I had received information; I said,
"Very well." and told my young man to make out the duplicate; I went round to try to shut the door, but he saw my intention, and ran off; I followed; he fell down, got up, and ran again.

JOSEPH DICKENSON
. I was coming down the town, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I saw the prisoner running; I pursued, and caught him; as I was taking him to the cage, I saw him stoop; I looked, and found this scarf.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was at Brentford, and met a man, who asked me where there was a pawnbroker's; I went to show him; he asked me to take these things in - he said he would give me sixpence, and the ticket - he told me to ask five shillings, and if they would lend it, I was to go and tell him; I went to tell him, and the gentleman came to take me.
GUILTY . Aged. 20.
Confined Six Months .

947.
THOMAS GOULBOURN
and
PHILIP NEWMAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 7 lbs. of beef, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Eden Frenholm
.

THOMAS EDEN FRENHOLM
. I am a butcher , and live at Stoke Newington
. This beef was in my shop on the 8th of April, about ten minutes before six o'clock in the evening- I saw the two prisoners walking backwards and forwards two or three times, and heard one of them say it would not do; I had seen Goulbourn before, lighting the lamps in the road; Goulbourn then came and took the heef - Newman was close by him; I was at the back of the shop; I went and took Goulbourn - Newman made off, but was taken the same evening.

JAMES CLARK
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took Goulbourn.

JOSHUA FREDERICK CLEMENTS
. I am an officer. I took Newman in about an hour and a half; he made great resistance.

FRANCIS MOORE
. I was in the shop. I saw the two prisoners come up together; Newman drew the beef to the edge of the window - they then went into a public-house; I then saw one of them come and take the beef - I cannot say which.
Prisoner NEWMAN. Q. Where did you see me? A. Coming along the pavement, and you drew the meat to the edge of the board.
Prisoner NEWMAN. This prisoner never saw me at all.
GOULBOURN'S Defence. This man was not with me; I never touched the meat.

GOULBOURN -
GUILTY . Aged. 33.
Confined Three Months .

NEWMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

948.
JULIA McCUEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 2 copper pots, value 12s. , the goods of
Richard Herbert
.

RICHARD HERBERT
. I am a boot-closer , and live in Adam and Eve-court
. I lost two pots from my back kitchen - the prisoner lodged with me; I had information, gave her in charge, and on the Monday morning I found this pot at Jackson's, in Gee's-court.

THOMAS JACKSON
. I live at No. 9, Gee's court, and deal in marine-stores. I bought this pot of Mr. Dobson, in Berwick-court.

JONATHAN DOBSON
. I am a broker. On Saturday, between two and three o'clock, the prisoner brought this pot, and asked me if I would buy it - I told her to untie it, and asked what she wanted for it; she said 7s. - I said it was too much, which it was - it weighed about 14 lbs., with the iron; I gave her 5s. 6d. for it, and sold it for 6s.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I met a woman, who asked if I would oblige her by selling this pot, and she would allow me 1s.; she said her landlord was seizing, and her children were starving - she told me to ask 7s.; this gentleman said he would give me 5s. 6d. - I came out and told her; she said,
"Take it."
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Six Weeks .

949.
THOMAS MANSFIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 2 bit-halters, value 18s., and 1 crupper, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Chamberlain
.

CHARLES CHAMBERLAIN
. I live at Alridge
; I am a carman , and drive hay and straw to town; I lost these two bit-halters and a crupper from my stable in my yard- I left them there on the night of the 9th of April, and missed them the next morning; the door had not been locked.

SAMUEL JOHNSON
. I am a saddler, and live in Turnmill street. The prisoner came and offered two bit-halters for sale, for 4s.; I gave him no answer, and he went away - I informed the constable, who took him.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am the constable. Johnson told me, and I took the prisoner - he said he had brought up two horses to the Ram inn, in Smithfield, and was going to take them home to Hertfordshire; I said if he would go there I should be satisfied, but he would not; I was forced to call in another officer - we found this crupper on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found the harness near Chigwell.
GUILTY . Aged. 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

950.
GEORGE PALMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , I slab-stone, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Bourne
.

THOMAS BOURNE
. I am a baker . I missed a slabstone on Friday last from the front of a cottage in Birdcage-field
.

JOHN CLAYTON
. I am a silk-weaver. I was passing Bethnal-green-road, on the morning of the 9th of April, about half-past eight, or near nine o'clock; I saw the prisoner and another cross from Hart's-lane, with this slab - they set it against a wall; I went down the road, and met the officer - the prisoner was about half a mile from Mr. Bourne's.

JOHN McWILLIAMS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I received information, and went to the place - the prisonerwas standing there; Clayton said, "That is one;" he ran off - I pursued, and took him; I then went and found the slab.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not intend to run away. I was going to my brother - I would have taken the officer to the house.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character, and stated that he would take him into his employ.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

951.
THOMAS WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 32 quires of paper, value 7s. , the goods of
William Howell
.

WILLIAM HOWELL
. I am a stationer . This paper has been mine, but I cannot swear I had not sold it.

WILLIAM CRAIG
. I stopped the prisoner with this paper near a mile from the prosecutor's.
NOT GUILTY .

952.
FREDERICK CAREY
and
FREDERICK GUY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 10 yards of calico, value 2s. , the goods of
James Hendry
.

JAMES HENDRY
. I am a hosier , and live in Great Newport-street
. On the 7th of April I lost ten yards of calico from inside the door; I did not miss it till it was brought back - our shop-mark is on it.

JOHN BOWRING
. I saw the two prisoners near the door; I saw Guy take the calico, and give it to Carey - we went and took them with it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoners received excellent characters.

CAREY -
GUILTY . Aged. 14.

GUY -
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Whipped and Discharged.

953.
JOSEPH ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 4lbs weight of ham, value 2s. , the goods of
Henry Parratt
.

JUDITH KING
. I saw the prisoner take the ham out of Mr. Parratt's window, in London-street
, and run down the street; I gave an alarm, and he was taken.

JAMES GRAY
. I saw the prisoner run, and three more in front of him; I passed the prisoner, thinking the others had the ham, but they had not; I then turned, and took the prisoner with this ham, which is my master's, Mr.
Henry Parratt
.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. This gentleman passed me, and said, "Where is that bacon?" I had not any - I took this up from the ground, and said, "I suppose this is it."
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

954.
GEORGE MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Charles Bricknell
, from his person .

JOHN CHARLES BRICKNELL
. I am a hosier . I was standing in a passage leading from Princes-street
to Leicester-square
; I felt a pressure at my pocket - I felt, and missed my handkerchief; I saw two persons near me, and took hold of one of them; a gentleman came up, and said he would point out the prisoner; he showed him to me in Coventry-street; I recognised him as one who had been behind me - on the road to the watch-house he spoke to a person, and my handkerchief was sent to the watch-house.

GEORGE WILLIAM IRESON
. I saw Mr. Bricknell standing in the street; the prisoner took a handkerchief from his pocket, and put it behind him - a boy, who was standing against a post, took it from him; I am certain he is the person - I pointed him out to the prosecutor.

THOMAS GOOK
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to me; the handkerchief was delivered to me by Harris.

JOHN HARRIS
. About half-past eight o'clock I was going to get some wood; I saw a mob, and went up; the prisoner called me, and told me to go to Peter-street, to
Jem Connolly
, and fetch the handkerchief, which I did.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. This gentleman took another boy who had picked his pocket. I went on to St. Martin's church, and back again - he then came, and charged me with it after he had let the other boy go: I said I would go and show him where the other boy was, as I saw a boy running with it; I met Harris, and told him to go to the boy - it is quite false for that gentleman to say he saw me pick the pocket; if he did, why did he not take me.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .

955.
WILLIAM RILEY
and
JAMES LITTLETON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 1 purse, value 1s., 8 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 11 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Richard Gowland
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

956.
THOMAS SMITH alias THOMAS FOWLER SMITH
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 36 lbs. weight of mustard, value 2l.; 36 lbs. weight of starch, value 1l. 12s. 9d.; 24 lbs. weight of packthread, value 17s.; 6lbs. weight of twine, value 5s. 6d.; 14 lbs weight of colour, value 14s.; 14 lbs. weight of pepper, value 1l. 3s.; 3 pints of blacking, value 3s.; 1000 nails, value 2l.; 2 tin boxes, value 2s.; 56 lbs. weight of soap, value 2l. 9s.; 1 box, value 2s; 1 chest, value 1s. 6d.; 2 casks, value 2s.; 80 lbs. weight of cloves, value 1l. 9s.; 14lbs. weight of carraway seeds, value 6s.; 4 1/2 lbs. weight of powder blue, value 6s. 9d.; 3 1/2 lbs. weight of Minerva green, value 7s.; 6 lbs; weight of Brunswick green, value 4s. 6d.; 5 1/2 lbs. weight of Oxford cotton, value 5s. 3d.; 8lbs. weight of rose pink, value 4s., and 3 bags, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Yates
and another, his masters. - Also for stealing, on the 8th of March , 7lbs. weight of nutmegs, value 2l. 2s.; 4 lbs. weight of galls, value 4s.; 4 lbs. weight of Italian juice, value 8s.; 5lbs. weight of gum arabic, value 7s.; 10 lbs. weight of capers, value 16s. 8d.; 7lbs. weight of arrow-root, value 5s. 3d.; 5 lbs. weight of almonds, value 9s.; 6 lbs. weight of tapioca, value 3s.; 23 lbs. weight of blue, value 1l. 9s.; 17 lbs. weight of ginger, value 19s. 6d.; 14 lbs. weight of sago, value 6s.; 14 lbs. weight of sal prunella, value 5s.; 8 lbs. weight of Dutch pink, value 4s.; 4 lbs. weight of crone yellow, value 8s.; 1 lb. weight of pepper, value 2s.; 4lbs. weight of red lead, value 8d.; 1 lb. weight of gum, value 3s.; 3 lbs. weight of isinglass, value 2l.; 6 bags,value 6s. 6d., and 1 chest value 1s. 6d., the goods of Edward Yates and another, his masters. - Also for stealing, on the 19th of March , 32 lbs. weight of starch, value 1l. 8s.; 2 gallons of vinegar, value 4s.; 3 lbs. weight of soap, value 1s. 6d.; 1 hempen bag, value 1s. 6d.; 1 stone bottle, value 1s. 6d.; 2 1/2 lbs. weight of mace, value 1l.; 1 gross of lamp cottons, value 2s.; 8 ozs. weight of cayanne pepper, value 2s.; 8ozs. weight of realing thread, value 8d.; 2 mandrills and 2 lamps, value 3s.; 54 brushes, value 1l.; 19s. 7d.; 19 pints of capers, value 1l.; 100 quills, value 2s.; 2 bottles of ink, value 5d.; 10 quires of writing paper, value 8s.; 11 lbs. weight of arrowroot, value 8s. 3d.; 2 lbs. weight of cinnamon, value 17s. 6d.; 1 brush, value 1s. 6d.; 2 boxes, value 1s. 6d.; 2 gallons of oil, value 1l. 12s. 6d.; 28 glass bottles, value 6s. 4d., and 1 stone bottle, value 5s., the goods of
Edward Yates
and another, his masters. Also for stealing, on the 4th of February , 18 lbs. weight of soap, value 10s.; 3 gallons of oil, value 1l.; 30 lbs. weight of starch, value 1l. 1s., and one stone bottle, value 3s., the goods of
Edward Yates
and another, his masters .
To which indictments the prisoner pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

957.
ANN KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 13 yards of printed cotton, value 7s. , the goods of
William Kemp Hodges
.

CHARLOTTE HODGES
. I am the wife of William Kemp Hodges, linen-daper , of the Minories
. The prisoner came to our shop, on the 6th of March, and asked to look at some prints - I shewed her some; she looked at about three, then took a piece of cotton from the counter, and ran away with it; I gave an alarm, she was pursued, and brought back with it.

RICHARD BOOTH
. I heard a cry of Stop thief! and took the prisoner, who was standing still, about one hundred yards from the shop - she had this print hanging on her arm.

WILLIAM KEMP HODGES
I saw the prisoner in my shop on the 6th of March; I was in the counting-house; Mrs. Hodges made an alarm, and the prisoner was brought back - the print has my mark on it.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

958.
SUSAN JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
George Knapp
.

GEORGE KNAPP
. I am a pawnbroker . and live in Golden-lane
. The prisoner came in on the 30th of March to redeem an apron; she asked the price of another apron, and pulled out some others; Hare watched her -I heard something snatched from the door, and she was brought back with this handkerchief, which is mine.

GEORGE HARE
. On the 30th of March I saw the prisoner pull the handkerchief from the door; she was then on the threshold - she put it under her shawl and was going off; I took hold of her - she said "Don't, don't;" I brought her back - the handkerchief has my master's mark on it.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

959.
WILLIAM HILLMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March
. 3 jugs, value 2s. 6d.; 12 pap boats, value 3s.; 4 busts, value 5s.; 65 egg-cups, value 1ls.; 58 cups, value 6s. 6d.; 54 saucers, value 5s. 6d.; 29 basons, value 7s.: 1 milk-pot, value 3d.; 7 glass cruets, value 14s.; 144 toys, value 2s.; 148 plates, value 18s. 6d.; 54 saltcellars, value 8s.; 12 coffee-cups, value 3s. 6d., and 1 china dog, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Mansfield
and another, his masters ; and
EDWARD PAYSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, he well knowing them to have been stolen .

JOHN MANSFIELD
. I manage the business of the prosecutors, who are earthenware manufacturer s, and live in Barbican
. Hillman was in their employ for three or four years, as a kind of porter - I was going along Smithfield on the 26th of March, and overtook Hargrave with a basket of goods on his head; he did not give me any information, but I sent a person to Payson's with my young man, who is not here; he brought a pattern of some goods; I went to Payson's lodging on the 2d of April, in Three Tun-court, Redcross-street
, and found him there - I told him I had accused my young man, Hillman, of robbing me, and he had confessed it, and said that Payson had received the goods and paid 6d. per dozen for them; he said he had not, but that he had received the goods for gown pieces, which Hillman had had of him, and he had given him some money besides; the price of the goods were two-thirds less than they could be purchased for on his own account - I saw the two prisoners afterwards together; Payson asked Hillman whether what I had said was true - Hillman said it was, about his paying 6d. a dozen for them; Payson denied having paid any money for them, except two or three shillings - there was property found in both their lodgings, cups, saucers, and a great many other things; the greater part was found in Payson's lodgings.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. What did you find at Hillman's? A. The officer has it; I had a communication with Hillman before I saw Payson, but not before I sent to him - I did tell Hillman that if he would confess the extent to which he had been robbing us, I would not prosecute him; and he said, what Hargrave had was all he had robbed us of.

GEORGE HARGRAVE
. I deal in earthenware, and live in Sandy-street, Bishopsgate. I have seen the prisoners, but not in company - I dealt with Payson once only, which was on the 26th of March; I bought twelve dozen of plates, five dozen of egg-cups, and four dozen and half of salts; I paid 1s. 3d. a dozen for the plates - it was no very great bargain - I could buy them at Mr. Mansfield's for 1s. 4d.; I have the articles now at home - I have sold about a dozen egg-cups; Mr. Mansfield saw me going along, and told me they were his; Payson told me he had bought them at Mr. Bullen's sale.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. Where does Mr. Mansfield live? A. In Barbican; I bought them between eleven and twelve o'clock, and he met me about one - I had seen Payson the day before in Petticoat-lane, where I stand every afternoon to sell goods; he asked me if I would buy some blue muffin-plates, and told me he lived at No. 3, Three Tun-court, Redcross-street - I offered him a 5l. note; there was some difficulty about changing it, and I went to Mr. Mansfield for change as I deal there - I told him I should go there; he made no objection - I returned in about two hours, and he was still there.

JOSEPH ORTON
. I am a constable. I was sent for toMr. Mansfield, and took Payson to the computer - I found on him 1l. 0s. 9d., and the key of his door; I went to his lodgings, and found the greater part of this property concealed under a bedstead, which goes back with folding doors, from the top to the bottom - here are three pairs of images, three china jugs, one blue mug, twelve blue papboats, four busts, one blue butter-pan, seventy-two eggcups, twenty-one blue basons, and a great variety of other things which Mr. Mansfield identified; Payson said he would bring witnesses to prove that he bought part of it of Mr. Mansfield - the next morning I asked him if he could bring those witnesses; he said,
"I never told you so" - I went with Howard to take Hillman, and on him was found a key which opens Payson's door.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. Did Payson tell you where he lodged? A. Yes; I did not know him before - it is a small room; the things were mostly under a bedstead - there were a number of basons in a closet, some earthenware in other parts of the room, and images on the mantel-piece; the other articles were on a sofa under a coat.

ROBERT HOWARD
. I am a constable. I went to Mr. Mansfield's and then to Hillman's lodging, where I got twelve coffee cups, five cruets, and one china dog - I found this key on him, which opens Payson's lodging.

The prosecutors not being able to identify the property, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

959.
JAMES HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 2 tea-pots, value 8s. 6d.; 1 jug, value 1s. 3d.; 1 pair of snuffers, value 4s. 6d.; 1 japan tray, value 2s.; 4 brushes, value 3s. 6d.; 2 cushions, value 1s. 2d.; 2 phosphorus boxes, value 6d.; 5 combs, value 3s.; 2 other combs, value 2s.; 1 gold ring, value 4s., and 72 pencils, value 2s. 3d., the goods of
John Sewell
and another, his masters .

JOHN SEWELL
, JUN. I am in partnership with
John Sewell
, of Fore-street
; we are jewellers and hardwaremen - the prisoner was our porter ; we suspected him, and spoke to the officer, who was in waiting, and took him on the 24th of March - he had been with us five or six years.

JOHN LACEY HAWKINS
. I am a marshalman. I watched the premises on the 24th of March - I took the prisoner on the opposite side of the way, and took him into his master's house; I saw him put his hat on a chair on his left hand - I said he should not put any thing down; I stopped down, and when I got up I saw this packet of pencils in the chair on his left hand - I did not see it come out of his hat; there were no persons present but Mr. Sewell and the prisoner - I searched the prisoner's house in Castle-street, Finsbury. to which he directed me, where I found these other articles; here is a metal tea-pot, a tea-tray, combs, brushes, phosphorus-boxes, and other things, and a gold ring.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. Have they been claimed? A. Yes, by Mr. Sewell; I believe there were two or three plated spoons which Mr. Sewell said he could not swear to, and I did not take them - I took the prisoner, into the back parlour at his master's, Mr. Sewell went up with us, but he got into the room before me; the room had been empty - I cannot tell how the parcel came on the chair.

MR. SEWELL re-examined. Q. What does the parcel contain? A. Pencils; there is a mark on the paper; most of the other things had a private mark on them; I believe them to be ours:; the prisoner sent two letters the next day - one to my mother, and one to myself; I have seen him write, and believe they are his writing - this is the one to my mother - ( reads.)

HONOURED MADAM, - On account of my unfortunate wife and children, I hope you will not press this charge against me; particularly when I assure you I intended to replace the articles, or to have given you the value for them. I hope you will take my unfortunate case into your consideration, and treat me with that lenity I know your feeling heart would wish; and, as in duty bound, I shall ever pray, Your's, J. HILL.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. Was there a relative of your's who lodged in the prisoner's house? A. Not that I know of; I have been in the country a good deal lately; I did not know till the other day that my mother used to visit a person at the prisoner's.

JAMES SEWELL
. I saw the prisoner take these pencils out of his hat, and put them on the chair.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you out when the prisoner was laid wait for? A. No, I was in the warehouse - I went up stairs with them; I went in first, with a light, and the prisoner went in next; I took the parcel out of the chair, and examined it - it has our mark on it; I did not know of any relation lodging at the prisoner's.
GUILTY . Aged 29.

960
THOMAS EEDLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March , 1 wooden box, value 4d.; and 400 oranges, value 19s. , the goods of
John Knill
.

JOHN KNILL
. I am a fruit broker , and live in Pudding-lane. A box, containing four or five hundred oranges, was on its way from a ship, at Cox's quay, to the warehouse - the prisoner was employed by my brother as a porter , to carry it - it has not been seen since.

HENRY KNILL
. I am the prosecutor's brother; I am a fruit cooper, and work the fruit on board the ships - the prisoner worked regularly as a porter; I had employed him many times before and I employed him on the 13th of March to carry these oranges from the vessel I was on board of, at Cox's quay
, to the seed warehouse, which is between Cox's quay and Thames-street
; he was to deliver it - to one of the warehouse men: I saw him go off with the box.

WILLIAM PARRY
. I am a porter - I followed the prisoner with another box of oranges, on the 13th of March - I saw him go on beyond the seed warehouse, which is about one hundred yards from the quay - I hailed him - he did not stop, but walked on, and turned the gateway, and I saw no more of him.

RICHARD BUTTER
. I am a porter. I saw the prisoner pitch a box of oranges on the block in King's Headcourt; I asked him where he was going - he took no notice of me - that was beyond the warehouse - I then passed on.

THOMAS BRIAN
. I am a porter. I was going into the King's Head public-house, to light my pipe - I met Tom Shields, who asked me to take a drop of beer; I came out, and he said, this box was to go to No. 112, Newgate-street, and if I would take it he would give me 1s.; I took it - the prisoner said nothing to me about it.

Q. Did you see the prisoner afterwards? A. Why, I did see him - but Shields is the man who employed me; the prisoner never mentioned a sentence to me concerning the box whatever; Shields was the man who employed me and paid me.
COURT. Q. Do you mean you never talked to the prisoner about it afterwards? A. I did not speak a word to him about it nor he to me; I met him on the way.
Q. Did you nod to each other, or say "How do you do?" A. It might be the case, for all that I know.

Q. Did not he mention about the oranges or the box? A. No; not who employed me - nor any thing about it: I did meet him on my journey from Pudding-lane to Newgate-street - I had the box on my knot; I cannot tell which side of the way he was; I cannot tell which way he was going - I knew where I was going myself; I rather think he might be about Cheapside.

Q. Did you pitch at all? A. Why I got rather tired, and the prisoner took it on his head, as I was rather tired - he carried it from Cheapside to where I was ordered to take it - to assist me, I rather thought, from where I pitched it.
Q. What made you tell me that you did not know that you had spoken to each other? A. I did not mention that.

Q. Do you know you are bound by your oath to speak the whole truth, as well as nothing but the truth - then the prisoner, when you pitched, and were heavy loaded and fatigued, carried it to this place, did he? A. Yes, he did take it on his knot, in Cheapside, to where I had been ordered to take it, to No. 112, Newgate-street.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is Shields here? A. I understand not; he employed me to carry this box, and said it belonged to a countryman, who was rather drunk, and could not carry it.

Q. Was the prisoner near Shields at that time? A. No; Shields was the person who said he would pay me, and did pay me - it is customary for us porters to give one another a lift, all in good-nature; I cannot say what it contained; I dare say oranges - I did not look into it -Shields agreed to give me one shilling, and he gave me half a crown.

Q. The prisoner never gave you a farthing? A. No; he has often given me a lift when I have been tired - I have known him three years; he never did assist me before, nor I him; I only meant to say that us porters are in the habit of doing it - Shields paid me when I came back; we did not speak a word to one another going back; it was not Shields who helped me; I never saw him till I got back and he paid me.

Q. Did the prisoner, directly or indirectly, employ you to carry that box? A. He never did: I was examined before the Lord Mayor; I told there every word that I have to-night - I said Shields agreed for 1s., and gave me 2s. 6d., and that the prisoner gave a lift on the road.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 31.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Six Weeks .

961.
THOMAS RICKARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 2 ozs. of tea, value 3d. , the goods of the
United Company of Merchants trading to the East Indies
.
MESSRS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM KEYS
. I am in the employ of the East India Company. On the 7th of April the prisoner was employed in a room on the ground-floor, at their warehouse in Cutler-street
; he was mending one of the chests; I saw him take some tea out, and put it into his left-hand pocket; I informed Mr. French, the assistant elder - this was between eight and nine o'clock in the morning.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you, the minute before, had any conversation with him? A. Yes; I had asked him for snuff - he did not put his hand in his pocket, take out some tea, and say, "This is tea which I forgot to deliver where I was directed;" nor say, "My God ! I have the tea in my possession which I ought to have left at home;" he was taken into custody in about ten minutes - he was in custody before nine o'clock.

WILLIAM FRENCH
. I am assistant elder to the East India Company. Keys gave me information, and I called the prisoner; I took hold of him; he wanted to get his hand from me to get to his pocket - I took him into the counting-house, and there put my hand into his left-hand pocket, which was half a yard long, and had been made for the purpose; I took out this tea, and put it on a sheet of paper; here are from two to three ounces of it - I gave him in charge, and went to examine the chest he had been working at; I found the lead had been cut at the side, and there was an aperture made that the hand could go in, and take the tea out; the tea found in his pocket exactly corresponded with that in the chest.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has he been in the Company's service? A. Sixteen or seventeen years.

JAMES TOMKINS
. I am in the employ of the East India Company. On the 7th of April I took the prisoner into custody, at the request of French; he rather tried to get his hand from Mr. French.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

962.
ELLEN FLINN
was indicted for a
misdemeanor . MESSERS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

JOHN MARTIN
. I am servant to Mr. Lockley a pastry-cook, of Newgate-street
, On the 31st of March, about halfpast ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came and asked for a penny cake, she gave me a shilling, and I gave her 11d. change; I afterwards saw Lee, the watchman, and showed the shilling to him - he gave it me again, and I put it into a drawer in which there was only a sixpence besides; the prisoner came again in about a quarter of an hour; she then asked for a penny cake, and gave me another shilling, which looked black on the head - I detained her, and called in the watchman; I called my master, and delivered the two shillings to him; he marked them in my presence, and they were delivered to the watchman.

WILLIAM LEE
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner in the shop - when she came out, I went in and saw the shilling, which Martin showed me; the prisoner went there a second time - I was called in and took her; I found 7 3/4d. in copper on her; these are the two shillings which were delivered to me.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a constable. The prisoner wasbrought to the watch-house - I searched her, and found 7 1/2d. in copper on her; the two shillings were delivered to me - I returned them to Lee.

JOHN FIELD
. I am inspector of counterfeit coin; these shillings are both bad - they are cast in the same mould, and are made of what is called white metal.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Six Months , and to
find Sureties .
OLD COURT.
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, APRIL 16.
Second Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

968.
SARAH EVANS
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Rushbrook
, on the 14th of March , and stealing 4 coats, value 10l.; 5 boys' dresses, value 8l.; 2 waistcoats, value 20s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 2l.; 3 yards of cloth, value 50s., and 1 pair of drawers, value 16s., his property .

CHARLES RUSHBROOK
. I live in Leather-lane, at the corner of Baldwin's-gardens
, and am a tailor . I went to bed about eleven o'clock at night on the 13th of March, and got up about a quarter-past six in the morning; I had left my house quite secure, but found a piece cut out of one of the shop shutters, round the corner in Baldwin's-gardens - it had been cut by an orger, and I found the piece inside that had been cut out; they then broke one of the squares of glass, and brought the property through the hole - they must have put a hand in to have got the property; I missed property worth 25l. or 30l. - I know nothing of the prisoner.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I am a Bow-street officer. On the 14th of March, about half past twelve, or one o'clock in the day, I saw the prisoner going down Sun-street, with this bag in a bundle-handkerchief; she was threequarters of a mile from the prosecutor's; two men were ten or fourteen yards behind her, and then went in front of her; I cannot say they were in her company - she went in a direction for Petticoat-lane - the two men then got in front of her; I knew one of them, which excited my suspicion, and in a street leading to Petticoat-lane I went up to the prisoner, and asked what she had got there; she said she did not know - I asked her where she had brought it from; she said she had met a man in Smithfield, who asked her to carry the bundle, and he would give her a shilling - I asked her where she was to carry it to; she said she did not know, but the man told her to follow him - the two men had then got in front of her, as far as they were before from her; I asked her if either of the men walking in front was the man who gave it her - after some hesitation she said it was the stoutest, and at that time one of the men looked round, and both walked fast; they turned the corner, and were out of sight in a minute - I took her to the office, with the bag, which contained this property.
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

964.
PATRICK O'DONNELL
and
PETER DALEY
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Elizabeth Coombs
, on the King's highway, on the 30th of March , at St. Luke, putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 bonnet, value 3s.; 1 shawl value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3d.; 1 pair of patterns, value 6d., and one sixpence, her property .

ELIZABETH COOMBS
. I am single , and live in May-place, Stamford-street, Blackfrairs-road. On Sunday night, or Monday morning, the 30th of March, between one and two o'clock, I was going home, and O'Donnell spoke to me, at the end of Fleet-street; he asked me where I was going - I never saw him before; I am certain he is the man; I told him I was going home; he said he would give me half-a-crown if I would take a walk along with him - I said I knew no place on this side the water, and he said he did; I turned, and went with him; he took me to Lion and Lamb-court, Golden-lane
- I was never there before; we did not go into a house; the patrol came up, and asked if I lived there; and he asked O'Donnell if he lived there, and he said Yes; the patrol told me I had better go home, it was quite time I was at home, and the man likewise - I turned from the prisoner, and asked the patrol to direct me to Blackfriars-bridge - he took me a little way below the brewhouse, and told me to go across Smithfield, and that was the way to the bridge; I had scarcely left the patrol a minute before O'Donnell came after me, tapped me on the shoulder, and told me he would give me another shilling if I would go back with him - I refused, and said I was going home; but I afterwards turned, and went back with him - when I came back to Lion and Lamb-court he showed me the house, No. 8, and told me that was the house I was going to; but instead of taking me into the house, he put one hand on my shoulder, and the other under my arm, and violently tried to push me into a place opposite, and I felt two more men trying to pull me in likewise; I screamed out for the watchman -O'Donnell then called out for Burke, and told him to stop the b-y b-chs throat; O'Donnell directly up with his fist, and struck me on the side of my head, and knocked me down in the court; I felt them pulling my things off as I lay in the court; I cannot say which of them it was - they pulled off my bonnet, shawl, handkerchief, and pattens; O'Donnell directly put one hand across my mouth and nose, and the other on my throat, and the others were pulling me, one by the legs, and the other by the shoulder - I heard some footsteps coming up the court: and directly they heard the footsteps, they left me, and ran into the house, No 8, opposite.

Q. Are you sure of O'Donnell doing what you have mentioned? - A. Yes; there were two besides him - I could not swear to either of them; I cannot say which of them pulled my things off: they were holding me on the ground while my things were being pulled off - O'Donnell held me on the ground while my things were pulled off; they were all three nearly together; while I was on the ground, O'Donnell struck me several times on my head, while I was being thrown down, and while I was down, and he put his hand over my mouth and nose - the other two men seemed to be in the place opposite when they began to pull me: I had a shilling and sixpence tied up in the corner of the handkerchief, which they took from me- I should not know either of the other two men: they all went into No. 8; the watchman came up - I was then on my hands and knees, trying toget up; I told him what had happened; he looked about for my things, but nothing was to be found; I also looked about for them - the watchman had a lantern, and there was a gas-light in the middle of the court; the watchman then went into No. 8, and I saw the prisoner Daley standing at the window of the first-floor, with his coat off - the house is only one story high; O'Donnell was lying in bed, with all the clothes covered over him; the watchman pulled the clothes down, but he could not make any sense of O'Donnell; he pretended to be very much intoxicated - I said, directly I saw him, that he was the man; they took Daley to the watch-house, and me also; they went back, and brought O'Donnell -Cooper, the officer, the watchman, the patrol, and Finch, were there; they all went into the house; Wood was also in the house. I believe, when Daley and I came down stairs with the watchman, my things laid opposite the door - I saw my bonnet, handkerchief, shawl, and pattens there.

Cross-examained by MR. BARRY. Q. With whom do you live? A. With my brother and sister - they lodge there; they lived at first in Brunswick-street: I had moved with them from there to this house, a week before -I board and lodge with them: I am an unfortunate girl; I have lived at St. Luke's workhouse since this; the Magistrate thought proper to send me there - my brother and sister know where I am; I had left home about eight o' clock that evening, or between eight and nine.

Q. Were you asked at the office at what time you left home, and said, at twelve at night? A. No, I was never asked at what time I left home; there was a second hearing; I was not then asked at what time I left home -I do not recollect your asking me the question; twelve o' clock is generally the time I return - I had the shilling and sixpence in my handkerchief; I had not received that out of doors that night - I dined and had tea at home: I had been in company with a person before, on the other side of the water; I had only been in company with one; it was a young man; I cannot say what time I spent with him - I did not drink with him at all.

Q. You do not know how many hours you were in his company? A. I was not "hours" at all, nor yet an hour; I cannot say how long I was with him - O'Donnell was a perfect stranger to me; I never saw him before.
Q. Was not the man who spoke to you in Fleet-street, a person named Burke? A. No, O'Donnell is the man.

Q. When the patrol spoke to you, what was the reason you went away without waiting for your half-crown? A. The patrol said I had better go home, and I took his advice - I had not got the half-crown; I turned away, and the patrol saw me below the brewhouse; when O'Donnell followed me, I refused to return at first, and then went, as he said he would give me another shilling - I did not at first object to go for the half-crown; that I recollect - I will say nothing but the truth; I do not know that I objected at first to have half a crown; there is one gas-light in the court; I do not know whether there is more - I had never been there before; I spoke to no woman on the road; O'Donnell spoke to no woman but myself - O'Donnell put his hand on my shoulder, and tried to push me into a place; I was not pushed in, as I put my hand to the side of the door, and hindered them from getting me in - it is a public privy; I saw nobody about till I felt two men pulling me - I cannot swear to those men; Daley is as near the height of one of them as possible - he is a common-sized man.

Q. Are we to understand you were pushed by one, and pulled by two inside, and yet they could not get you in? A. I am not certain the two were inside: they did not get me in, for O'Donnell knocked me down in the court - I called out, when I found there was more than one - that was before a hand was put before my mouth, and O'Donnell after that cried out, "Stop the b-y b-cb's mouth.

Q. Did you not understand that was to stop your calling? A. I thought it might be so, till he put his hand over my mouth and nose; I heard nothing about a lark - no liberties had been taken with my person that night.

Q. Did you tell the Magistrate the persons you could not identify were pulling your legs and shoulders while you were on the ground? A. Yes, I did; the watchman and others searched for my things before I went into the house, and when we came out, they were found on the ground; the patten laid at a little distance, but the other things were thrown in a heap together, not tied up.

Q. How many people had assembled at that time? A. I did not see any; I did not notice a woman looking out of her window; I think there are houses only on one side of the court; when I went into the house, I said I thought Daley looked like one of the men; I did not say Sheridan, the landlord, was one - I spoke to nobody but O'Dounell; I said Daley looked like one, but I could not swear to him; when O'Donnell came into the watch-house I said I knew his voice, and he was the man; I did not say I knew Daley's voice; I did not speak to one Kenney.

JAMES McDONALD
. I am a patrol. On the 30th of March, at a quarter before two o'clock in the morning, I was coming down Playhouse-yard: I heard some foot-steps at the end of Lion and Lamb-court, which is in St. Luke's,and in Middlesex; I called the wathchman to bring his light - he came with his light, and three or four men and one woman were in the entry; I asked the woman what she was doing there, she said she was brought there by one of the men; I told her she had better go home, and she walked away; I immediately asked the men if they lived there - they said they did live in that court; I told them it was time they should be at home and when I came down to the end of the yard, the girl was standing by a post, and asked me to direct her to Blackfriars-road; I knew three of the men - that was Daley, O'Donnell, and Burke; I knew them by seeing them come out of their place to go to work of a morning; I went a little way down the lane, with the prosecutrix, pointed to the bottom of the lane, and directed her home; I crossed over to the other side of the way, and while standing there I saw O'Donnell come out of Playhouse-yard, and go in the same direction as the girl had gone, and in two or three minutes I saw her and him returning up the lane again - walking arm-in arm; they came up to Playhouse-yard, and turned the corner again; and after turning the corner, there were three or four of the same party standing talking to the watchman on the opposite side of the way; and in the course of half a minute, they left him and proceeded up the court after the man and woman; I immediately proceeded over to another watchman, who was coming down the lane; I and two watchman went from the other side of the way to the corner of the yard, and heard a person screaming; we ran up Lion and Lamb-court, and saw the prosecutrix rising from the ground, apparently very much dejected, her hair very much disordered, and all over mud and wet, she told me something, and made her complaint to me; we went to search if we could find any of the property she had lost but found none - she pointed to a house, we went in, and while looking below (there was a man and his wife in bed) we heard a window pulled up, and footsteps up stairs; we immediately went up stairs and met Daley coming from towards the window - the prosecutrix then came up stairs and said that was one of them, that was Daley, and on looking round there were some more men asleep in a bed; she did not point out any of them, but on the third bed, on coming towards the door, we saw a heap on the bed, and on pulling the coverlid down we found O'Donnell underneath, with his clothes on; we tried to awake him, to get sense into him, but he appeared quite speechless, we could not get a word from him - the man and woman who were below came up stairs, and said he had not been out of bed since nine o'clock that morning; on taking hold of his hand to look at it, the sleeve of his jacket was all over wet mud - we took Daley into custody, and brought him out at the door, and on coming out of the door of the house the watchman pointed to the things that laid in the court; (there were three beds in the room, the prosecutrix did not recognise any body on the second bed); the watchman picked the things up and took them to the watch-house with Daley, and as we turned to come on I saw a handkerchief lying down, which I picked up, and told the girl to tie it round her neck, which was quite bare; and when we came just to the bottom of the court I met Cooper, the inspector; I delivered the girl to him, and remained close in sight of the premises till he returned again with the watchman - they went into the house and brought O'Donnell down, and took him to the watch-house - I remained behind; I know nothing more.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell the prosecutrix she had better go home? A. I did; she stood with O'Donnell close at the corner; the others were at a distance from them, at the turn of the court - she said one of the men had brought her there.
Q. Then of course she gave you to understand there were other men there? A. No.

COURT. Q. What were her words? A She said she had been brought there by one of the men: those were her words; that was not the first time, but when we went to her assistance - when I first went to her she said nothing about any men.

MR. BARRY. Q. She pointed out O'Donnell in bed? A. We turned the clothes down, and she said she could swear that was one of the men; we could not make him understand, speak, or move - she said Daley was one of the men, that was before we saw O'Donnell - the man and woman who came up were both undressed; there were seven inmates altogether - I do not know their names; I knew Sheridan by sight, as I had his brother in custody a little while ago; I did not know him by name till then - I have ascertained that he keeps the house; I have been a patrol these five years - I believe there are twelve houses in the court, several of them had their windows up and people looking out; I saw none of the inhabitants of the court down below except the people of that house; a window next door but one to the house was open, and a person looking out at No. 10 - the next house to that is empty; there is a small gutter in the court - I found the handkerchief close to the end of the gutter, it was a pocket handkerchief - I found one patten lying by the side of it.
COURT. Q. She pointed out Daley as one of the men? A. Yes; he was coming from the window, with his coat off - he was the first we saw on going into the room.

ROBERT WOODS
. I am a watchman. On the morning of the 30th of March, about a quarter before two o'clock, the patrol called me for a light - I was opposite Playhouse-yard; I went up to Lion and Lamb-court with him, and saw O'Donnell, Daley and Burke, all three standing there together - I knew Burke before, but not the other two; I am certain of the prisoners - the patrol told the prosecutrix to go home; she went away -O'Donnell went after her in a few minutes, and I saw him come back with her; Burke came down Playhouse-yard over to me, and spoke to me - then Daley and two or three more, who were standing there, went up Playhouse-yard; I had spoken to them before that - I heard a scream of Watch! called out; I went up Lion and Lamb-court, where the scream came from, and the prosecutrix was just getting up; she pointed to No. 8 - I went in there with the patrol and another watchman; I saw Daley, who had just got his coat off, going to bed - several more were in bed there; I saw O'Donnell in bed with the clothes covered all over him - Coombs said Daley was one of them; we took him to the watch-house with her; as we went along Daley said it was not him, and said, "Here is a shilling for you to drink, it was not me, and I nudged you when you were there; it was O'Donnell;" O'Donnell was in bed covered with the clothes, and appeared to be very much in liquor; Coombs said at the watch-house that she could swear to him by his voice - she had pointed him out when he was in bed; when we came down, Finch picked up a shawl, bonnet, pair of pattens, and a handkerchief, and gave it to me to take to the watch-house - they were all rolled up together.

Cross-examined. Q. All rolled up together? A. There was a shawl, patten, and bonnet rolled up together when it was given to me; I did not see them picked up- I do not think Brown the watch-house keeper is here; he was examined at Worship-street, and sworn.

Q. Where were you standing at the commencement of this? A. Opposite Playhouse-yard; I had been walking about two or three minutes - I did not see the prosecutrix come up to the court the first time; I might be in another part of the lane - she did say she had been brought there by one of the men.
COURT. Q. When did she say so? A. I forget now; it was when I was up the court - I do not know whether it was after she was told to go home; I went up the court when I heard the screams.

WILLIAM FINCH
. I am a watchman. I went to Lion and Lamb-court on Monday morning, the 30th of March, about ten minutes before two o'clock; the patrol came tome - I went into No. 8, and saw Daley standing by the window with his coat off; the girl gave charge of him, and I took him to the watch-house - I pulled the bedclothes down, and saw O'Donnell there dressed; I tried to rouse him - he pretended to be so intoxicated, no sense could be beat into him; the girl saw me pull the clothes down; I felt wet mud on his nose - the girl charged Daley first; I came back after taking him, and took O'Donnell to the watch-house; the girl pointed him out in the bed, but he seemed so drunk we could do nothing with him till after I took the other to the watch-house; I picked up the shawl in the court, and gave it to the patrol; I saw the bonnet lying in the gutter, but nothing else; I did not see the handkerchief - they were right opposite the door of No. 8.

Cross-examined. Q. How far is the gutter from the house? A. A very little distance - the court is very narrow; I found the shawl very near the gutter, the bonnet lying in the gutter, and a patten was found in the gutter, but I did not see it - I went to the watch-house; Coombs said nothing in my presence of knowing any body's voice.

WILLIAM EDWARD COOPER
. I am an inspector of the watch. On the morning of the 30th of March, about two o'clock, I was in Playhouse-yard, and met Daley in the custody of Finch and Woods: I took the girl to the watch-house - I afterwards went to No. 8, Lion and Lamb-court, and saw O'Donnell in bed, with all his clothes on except his flannel jacket, and covered over with the bed clothes; I shook him, and told him it was of no use to play tricks, and if he did not come out of bed I would pull him out; he got out of bed, and put his flannel jacket on - he then put one of his boots on up stairs, and the other down; I took him to the watch-house - the minute he entered the watch-house he began to speak; the prosecutrix said,"That is one of them, I can swear to him by his voice" - she had not seen his face then; one of the arms of his jacket was wet, and the other was wet round the cuff; the prosecutrix's things were delivered to me at the watch-house- the bonnet and shawl were delivered to me by Brown, the watch-house keeper; the handkerchief was given to me by the prosecutrix - she had it round her neck when I took her to the watch-house; Brown is not here; I received them in the watch-house - the patrol gave me one patten in Playhouse-yard, and Brown the other; I have had them ever since - I found no money in the handkerchief; there was no knot in it.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there the slightest appearance of there having been a knot in it? A. It was as she gave it to me in the morning when she was going away to the office, just before eleven o'clock; Brown was not bound over to come here.

MR. BARRY to
JAMES McDONALD
. Q. Why did you not keep the handkerchief? A. Her neck was bare, and she had nothing on her head; nothing had been said to me about money being in it then; when I picked it up and gave it to her she did not ask me where the 1s. 6d. was -I picked that and a patten up close to the water-run; the things were nearly close together, but not quite.
COURT. Q. Did you see the other things lying about? A. They were all picked up before I got to them; I saw the shawl lying down, but, it being dark, I saw nothing else.

MARY CANNON
. I live at No. 20, Playhouse-yard, which is five houses from Lion and Lamb-court - I know No. 8 there. On the morning of the 30th of March, after two o'clock, I saw the prosecutrix going into No. 8 with the watchman, and as soon as she entered the lower room I saw the one pair of stairs window open, and saw a bundle chucked out of the window, but what was in it I cannot tell - Daley chucked it out; I knew him before - I have often seen him in the court, and at the door; there was a candle on the window-ledge, so that I could see him; I am certain it was him - he had no coat on; it was a small sized bundle; I cannot say how large, because I only saw it by the light of the candle - I could not see where it fell, because there is a privy between my window and the house, so that I could not see the bottom of the court - I had to look sideways; my house is on the opposite side, four or five yards from No. 8; No. 7 is directly opposite to me - only one side of the court is called Playhouse-yard, and the other Lion and Lamb-court; I have not to turn a corner to go to the house.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first give an account of this? A. On Tuesday I went to Cooper's house; I did not call out that a bundle was thrown out, because I did not know the girl had been robbed - I heard a scream; there was a stir in the court - I am a shoe-binder, and single; I have lived there nearly four years - I was in bed, but heard screams, and got up; I am an English woman - a great many Irish live in the court; I saw the prosecutrix in the watehman's hands, and could have called over to them if I had liked; they were not above five yards from me.

JURY. Q. When you saw the bundle thrown out, was the patrol outside or inside? A. Inside; I remained at the window till he and the prosecutrix came out - I spoke of this on Monday; but did not tell Cooper till Tuesday.

WILLIAM FINCH
. I picked up a shawl, and gave it to McDonald, I think or Woods.

JAMES McDONALD
. Finch did not give me the shawl; it was never in my possession.

ROBERT WOODS
. The shawl, bonnet, and one patten were given to me, but I do not know who by, I am sure, in the bustle.

ELIZABETH COOMBS
. This is my handkerchief; I know it by the colour - I have had it a good bit: I believe my sister hemmed it; when it was given back to me my money was not in it; I never thought about the money then - it had been tied up in one single knot; it could not have fallen out unless it was untied - the bonnet is mine; I trimmed and lined it myself; the shawl I know by a piece out of the corner of the border - I know the pattens; I had had them about a week or a fortnight: all the things are mine, and what I had on when I went into the court.

O'DONNELL'S Defence. I had nothing to do with her; I never raised my hand to her, nor hurt her; I was not near Blackfriars-bridge that night; I never left Golden-lane - I never went further than the lane: I was never in Fleet-street. The watchman says he took me out of bed in my clothes; I had my boots, jacket, and waistcoat off; I had nothing to do with the woman.

DALEY'S Defence. I know nothing about it, except as I came into the court I saw the watchman and this woman - I heard her call the watchman to show her a light; I saw her and Burke at the end of the court - the watchmanshowed her a light; she said she had got a farthing instead of a shilling from Burke - the watchman asked if we lived in the court; we said we did: he told us to go in and go to bed - I stood talking to the watchman, and know nothing more.

PATRICK KENNEY
. I am a labouring man. On the 30th of March I lodged at No. 8, Lion and Lamb-court. About two o'clock in the morning the prosecutrix came into the house, and said I was the person who knocked her about outside; I had been in bed since between nine and ten o'clock, and did not get up till this affair; I am married, and my wife is in Ireland - she said, "That is the man."

COURT. Q. Was she pointing to you or to any body else? A. She did, and the watchman said, "He is not Burke;" I do not know the watchman; (looking at the witnesses) I cannot swear to any of them - I cannot say whether they were there that night; I think three watchmen came in with her - I have known O'Donnell two years and Daley half a year; they are labourers, and bore good characters.

ELIZABETH COOMBS
. I do not recollect seeing this man; I swore to nobody but O'Donnell.

JAMES McDONALD
. I went into the room with Coombs, and saw Kenney; Coombs did not speak of him at all; he was in his shirt - she said nothing to him.

WILLIAM FINCH
. I went with Coombs; Kenney jumped out of bed in his shirt when we went into the room; Coombs made no charge against him in my hearing.

ROBERT WOODS
. I do not recollect seeing Kenney there.

PATRICK SHERIDAN
. I live at this house, and am the landlord. I was in bed with my wife and asleep; I was disturbed about half-past two o'clock, and the very moment Coombs came in she said, "This is one of the men - I will take my oath this is one of them:" I had been in bed since nine o'clock.

COURT. Q. Did she address herself to you, that you were one? A. Yes; the moment the watchman turned his lantern over me, she said, "That is one of them;" there was no light in my house before the watchman came.

JAMES McDONALD
. Sheridan and his wife were in bed- Coombs did not charge him as being the man, or one of them; she did not speak to him down stairs, nor of him - the watchmen were looking about the house, but these people were in bed.

WILLIAM FINCH
. Coombs did not charge Sheridan as being one of the men in my presence; I saw him in bed - two of us were up stairs, and one down.

ROBERT WOODS
. I saw Sheridan that night: Coombs said nothing about him in my presence - the watchman were looking about in different places, some in one place, and some in another; Sheridan slept in the parlour, and Kenney up stairs.

PATRICK SHERIDAN
. All the watchmen had lights. I have known the prisoners four years; they are honest hardworking men.

JAMES GHRIMES
. I am a labourer, and lodge in this house. I was asleep up stairs on this night; the prosecutrix said nothing to me, but she gave charge of Sheridan and kenney, who slept in my bed - I have known the prisoners three years; they are honest men.

ELIZABETH COOMBS
. I never got my 1s. 6d.; it could not have fallen out of the handkerchief it was tied in.
Six witnesses deposed of both the prisoners' good characters.

O'DONNELL -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 23.

DALEY -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 22.
Before Mr. Justice Guzelee.

965.
WILLIAM BAKER
was indicted for that
he, on the 21st of February
, at St Andrew, Holborn, feloniously did falsely make, forge, and counterfeit a certain order for payment of money , which is as follows:
St. Ann's Union.

MR. THOMAS, - Sir, You will please to pay the bearer, for
Richard Power
, three pounds, for three weeks due to him, a country member, and you will much oblige, yours, &c.

2, Brown's-building, Stanhope-street, J. BESWICK, Mr. Thomas, Gray's Inn-lane. Feb. 21, 1829. with intention to defraud John Thomas, the said
John Thomas
, on whom the said false, forged, and counterfeited order for payment of money was made, then and there, being entrusted with, and having in his hands and possession, as the landlord of a certain public-house known by the sign of the Crown and Barley Mow. in Gray's Inn-lane, a certain large sum of money, to wit, 30l., belonging to
William Ireland
and others, members of a friendly society, called the St. Ann's Union, meeting at the said public-house, for the purpose of enabling the said John Thomas to pay, and that he might pay all orders for payment of money made by
John James Beswick
, the Secretary of the said Society, upon the said
John Thomas
, for claims made, and monies due to any of the members of the said society, according to the rules and regulations thereof; against the Statute, &c.

2d COUNT, that he, on the same day, at the same parish, feloniously did utter and publish as true, a certain false, forged, and counterfeited order for payment of money, well knowing the same to be false, forged, and counterfeited, which is as follows - (setting it out as before.) with intent to defraud the said
John Thomas
; against the Statute.

3d COUNT like the second, only stating the intent to be to defraud
John James Beswick
.

4th COUNT the same, only stating the intent to be to defraud
William Ireland
and others.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN THOMAS
. I am landlord of the Crown and Barley Mow, Gray's Inn-lane
. The St. Ann's Union Benefit Society is held at my house, Mr. Beswick is the secretary; he leaves money in my hand to pay any orders he may send for money; on Saturday, the 21st of February, I remember seeing the prisoner in front of my bar in the evening, between six and seven o'clock (my wife, who has seen him before, is not here) - he produced a cheque, and said he had brought that from Mr. Beswick for 3l. for a country member who had broken his arm - I looked at the cheque, and saw that it was not Beswick's hand writing; I told him it was not Mr. Beswick's hand-writing - he said he knew that, Mr. Beswick was out of town, at a funeral, being an undertaker, and that Mrs. Beswick directed her son to write it; I accordingly gave him the 3l., and put the cheque on the file of the society.

COURT. Q. Did the prisoner himself produce that cheque to you or to your wife? A.
