He produced it to me;my wife called me down stairs to him - my wife delivered the cheque into my hands in his presence; when I came down. I saw the prisoner standing in front of the bar; my wife said, "This gentleman has brought a cheque from Mr. Beswick for 3l.;" he stood in front of the bar, and saw her give me the cheque - I looked at it, and told him it was not Mr. Beswick's hand-writing, and gave it back into his hand again: he told me he knew it was not Mr. Beswick who wrote it, that Mr. Beswick was out of town, and Mrs. Beswick directed her son to write it; I did not ask who he was.
Prisoner. That is not the person who gave me the money, it was his wife - he never gave the cheque into my hand. Witness. I gave it to him myself.
COURT. Q. You put the cheque on the file of the society, where was that kept? A. It hung up in the bar; the club meet on the 3d and 4th Monday in every month.

JOHN JAMES BESWICK
. I am secretary to the St. Ann's Union Benefit Society , that is the title. I have a cheque which I got from Mr. Thomas - I have looked at the name"J Beswick," on it; it is not my hand-writing - there is no member named
Richard Power
, nor ever was; on the 21st of February I lived at No. 2, Brown's-buildings, Stanhope-street, Clare market - this "J. Beswick" is not my hand-writing - I know nothing whatever of the origin of it; I never authorised any body to sign it in my name or to issue it; I have a son named James and another named John, but he was not at home, nor was he on the 21st of February; he is in service in London - this " J. Beswick" is not the hand-writing of any of my family.

JAMES BESWICK
. I am the son of John James Beswick, and was fourteen years old last January. I never wrote this order, and know nothing about it; it is not my writing.

WILLIAM IRELAND
. I am a member of the St. Ann's Union , and was so on the 21st of February - there are other members besides me; I subscribe to the funds - if I am taken ill, or disabled, I receive support from the funds of the Society.

GEORGE SALTER
. (Looking at the order.) I know the prisoner; I am a carpenter, and live at No. 6, Osborne-street, St. James' - I have seen the prisoner write a great many letters; I believe this order to be his hand-writing, but cannot swear that it is.

COURT. Q. How long have you known him? A. Nineteen years - he has been in my employ; he kept my books for the last twelve months - I had frequent occasion to see him write; I suppose the whole of the order to be his hand-writing - it is a good deal like his writing - I have trusted the prisoner to receive and pay money, 40l. or 50l. at a time; he always did it faithfully - he behaved honestly; he had been very much reduced till he came to my house - I used to employ him as well as I could.

JOHN THOMAS
re-examined. This is the order I received from the prisoner, and put on the file of the Society, on the evening of Saturday, the 21st of February; I gave it to Beswick on the Monday following, in the evening - it had been on the file till then; nobody but my own family had access to the bar - I know it to be the same paper, because I put my hand-writing on it.

THOMAS GOOK
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 4th of March, in Osborne-street, St. James', at Mr. Salter's house; I searched him after I got to the office, and found this paper, among a number of others; this induced me to go to Mr. Beswick's - I told him, both before I found the paper, and after, that he was charged with forging certain orders; he wished me to allow him to put that paper into the fire; I told him he had had plenty of time to destroy any thing he chose before I took him - I then placed him in the back office, among a number of other prisoners: I observed him watching me very closely - I had occasion to go into the Magistrates' room, and after returning from the Magistrates' room, I found he was gone from where I had placed him: the place he had been in was not locked; I immediately ran out of the office door, and observed him turning the corner into Blenheim-street, about fifty yards from the office - I followed, and overtook him; I have known him twenty years - he bore an excellent character.
The order was here read, as set out in the indictment; the paper found on the prisoner was verbatim the same, except not being headed "St. Ann's Society."

Prisoner's Defence. I am unprepared with Counsel, having had so little time; I never knew a word of this charge till I had a note from the solicitor on Saturday - the keeper of Clerkenwell prison did not know I was to be tried here; I understood it was for a fraud.
MR. PHILLIPS. The landlady is here, if the prisoner wishes to examine her.
Prisoner. I have nothing to ask her.
The Court inquired if the prosecutors were prepared to produce any rules of the Society, authorising the secretary to draw upon Mr. Thomas. - Mr. Phillips replied in the negative.
GUILTY (of uttering). Aged 56.

p.rs: Recommended to mercy by the Jury, on account of his former good character, and his reduced situation.[This case stands reserved for the consideration of the Twelve Judges.]

div1.p:
There was another indictment against the prisoner for a similar offence, committed on the 11th of February
, upon which no evidence being offered , he was
ACQUITTED .

966.
STANLEY SHARP
was indicted for
feloniously forging an acceptance to a certain bill of exchange , which is as follows: 18th September, 1828.

Two months after date pay to me, or my order, 7l. Accepted,
John Pettit
.
WILLIAM PETTIT
.

Mr.
John Pettit
, 17, Seymour-street, Bryanstone-square. with intent to defraud
John Pettit
; against the Statute.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same with a like intent.

EDWARD SAYER PETTIT
. I am a draper, and live at Greenwich. I have a brother John, and one named William, who was unfortunate in business, and was in prison; he lived at Greenwich also - I know John Pettit, who lived in Seymour-place, Bryanstone-square; I produce a forged bill for 7l. On the 18th of September I saw my brother william draw a bill of the same date and amount exactly - the one I produce is the prisoner's hand-writing; the whole of it: he did live at Sheerness, but on the 18th of September he was a prisoner in the King's Bench, and was so on the 21st of November, when this bill became due - shortly before that I received 7l. from my brother William, which I gave to my mother; to pay the original bill with, that had been paid to the prisoner, but I am certain neither the signature, acceptance, nor the indorsements, William Pettit and
Edward Sayer Pettit
, are my brother's hand-writing - he had dealings with the prisoner, who was an attorney; the bill is receipted in the prisoner's writing.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Here is a receipt to the bill in the prisoner's writing? A. Yes, and the letters C.B.P.

Q. That means Copy of the Bill of Pettit's - why not tell us before, that those letters were there? A. I was asked about the indorsements; there is no stamp to it - my father did accept a bill, of which this is a verbatim copy, but without a stamp - the original has never been presented for payment, but we have bad a letter about it; this is the original bill (looking at one produced by the prisoner); my mother is nearly blind, and did not know but she was paying the original bill - I have a letter stating that the bill was not paid, and we must look to it; we received that the next evening.
Q. Well, it was not paid in full? A. All but 3s.; the original bill was given to the prisoner.
Q. Have there not been continual quarrels between your family and the prisoner, about law bills? A. Yes.

COURT. Q. Was the letter written before the bill became due? A. After; the post-mark is the 22d of November, but the letter is not dated - one came the same morning from the holder of the bill; I and my brother William paid the original bill to the prisoner - he would not take it without my indorsement; there is a receipt for 7l. on the copy.

ANN PETTIT
. I am the wife of
John Pettit
. I received 7l. from my son about the 17th or 18th of November - we at that time lived in Seymour-place, Bryanstone-square: the money was given to me to pay a bill; on the 21st of November the prisoner came to Seymour-place - I had not enough by 3s., and I paid him 6l. 17s., telling him he should have the remainder in the evening; he was in the Bench that day, but he came to me between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning - he said he had brought the bill, and presented it to me; he said he came for payment of the bill, and next day I received this letter (looking at it) from him - I know it to be his hand-writing; he only said he had brought the bill for payment, and gave me this paper - I did not know but it was the original bill; nobody else was at home - my husband generally goes out for a walk between nine and ten o'clock, and returns about one; I saw the prisoner write this receipt on the back - he then went away; he had called on the 19th for it, but I told him I should not pay it till the three days grace were up - he had a paper in his hand then; what it was I do not know - if he had said the paper was only a copy I should not have paid him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he never sue your family for a bill of costs? A. No, not a just bill; he sued two of my sons, but not these sons; I did not look at the bill, for knowing him to be the holder, I thought it was all right.

COURT. Q. Did you look at it when he brought it? A. No, he laid it on the table; I doubled it up, and put it away; but next morning, I found it was not the right bill - we have had a letter from one Rogers, demanding payment of the original bill; the prisoner came twice before, I paid it; he never sent for the 3s.; we sent to the King's Bench to get the bill, but he would not give it up.

WILLIAM JOHN REYNOLDS
. I am an agent. I went to Greenwich to settle an account with
William Pettit
, a few days after this was paid; Pettit gave me two letters, one signed Rogers, and the other Sharp; I went to his mother, and she gave me the copy of the bill - I found the prisoner in the strong-room of the King's Bench; I shewed him this piece of paper, and asked if he had not received 7l.; he said No, not 7l., but that the paper was his handwriting; I said it was not William Pettit's wish to do any thing against him, provided he gave up the original bill-he said,"I cannot, for I have paid it away to a Mr. Rogers;" at that time Rogers was coming up stairs, and said, "Who makes use of my name;" Sharp said, "This person has come about that bill of Pettit's;" Rogers said, "I have given value for it, and if not paid to-day, I will sue all the parties;" I went to Sharp a day or two after, and said he had better give up the bill, and Pettit would drop all proceedings; he said he could not; and said, "if you look on the back of the bill. you will see C.P.B., which means Copy of Pettit's Bill," but it is C.B.P.;
Edward Pettit
and I went to him again a week or ten days after; he said,"I have come up with instructions from my brother to get a warrant, but if you will give up the bill, nothing shall be done;" he said he could not do it, and a warrant was lodged for a fraud.

Cross-examined. Q. He could have avoided all proceedings by handing you back the original bill? A. Yes, I told him so; Pettit and him have not been at law - he was employed by a married sister of Pettit's - I live in Drummond-street, Euston-square; sometime after the warrant was lodged, he shewed me the original bill; he said he had got it back, and would send a person to meet Pettit about it, which he did.

JOHN PETTIT
. I lived in Seymour-place. The signature to this bill is not my writing, nor is the name
William Pettit
my son's writing; the body of the bill is not written by either of us.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the prisoner ever take proceedings against your and your sons George, William, and Edward? A. No: Mr. Barnard is my son-in-law; he might take proceedings against two of his sons, but not against three, nor against me.

The prisoner, in his defence, stated that he had been engaged in law proceedings for William Pettit, who had compounded with his creditors, and paid him 7l. in discharge of his claim, and he was in the habit of copying all his bills; on the day in question he called for payment, and as Mrs. Pettit had not the whole amount, he left her the copy, stating that he would give up the original when the balance was paid; that the letter produced was not dated, and might have been written before it was due, and that he had repeatedly offered to give the bill up on receiving the balance.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Recorder.

967.
JOHN HARRIS
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Towers
, on the 14th of November , at Christchurch, and stealing therein 36 yards of trimming, value 7s.; 20lbs. of cotton, value 3l.; 10lbs. of worsted, value 30s.; 32 pieces of ribbon, containing in length 36 yards each, value 15s., the goods of the said John Towers .

JOHN TOWERS
. I live at No. 46, Phoenix-street, in theparish of Christchurch, Spitalfields
, and am a silk-manufacturer - I rent the house, and know the prisoner; he was never in my employ. On the 14th of February, about six o'clock in the evening; I went out to Wood-street, on business - I left my housekeeper,
Maria Pritchard
, in the house; the house door is kept shut at that time of day - I returned at half-past seven o'clock, and found things the same as I had left them, but I did not examine the warehouse at that time, and am not aware of any thing being gone, as the doors were closed as I had left them; the warehouse is part of my dwelling-house: after my return, I was sitting by my fireside, in the room over the warehouse, and thought I heard something like a bolt snap; I sent my son down with a light, to see what it was, as I was very tired - I trusted to what he said: I went down to the warehouse about half-past eight o'clock, and missed thirty-six yards of trimming, value 7s. 6d., and 20 lbs. of cotton, worth 3l., 10lbs. of worsted, worth 30s., and thirty-three pieces of ribbon, of thirty-six yards each, worth 15l.; I am quite certain all these things were safe when I was last in the warehouse - I saw twenty-four yards of one of the pieces of ribbon about a month afterwards, at a public-house in Wheeler-street; I was quite certain it was my goods - the prisoner was not then in custody: I found my back door had been forced open: it had been locked - I observed some grease just where the bolt went, and the mark of some instrument having forced it - the bolt of the lock was forced from the socket; I had left the warehouse at six o'clock, and gave my boy the key to lock the door; I locked the front door, but not the back.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. When had you seen the property safe? A. At the time I went out; I am sure the drawers were secure, and the goods in them; I had seen them in the course of the day - no persons but customers have access to the warehouse; I am in a small way of business - I may have six customers in the course of the day: the things could not be taken without forcing the door; I have seen some cotton and silk the same colour as I lost, but I cannot swear to that.

JOHN TOWERS
. JUN. I am fourteen years old next month. On this day my father went out about six o'clock, leaving nobody that was engaged in the business but myself; the back door of the warehouse was open when my father left - I shut it directly; he went and locked it - the back door opens into a yard - a person could easily get to the yard without going through the house; all was safe then - I locked the doors, gave the light to the servant, and went out directly; the street door was locked also - nobody could get in except by force; the servant could not open the street door, for I took the key; I returned with my father about half-past seven o'clock and went up stairs - I was playing with the baby, and my father thought he heard a noise; I went down with a light, and found the back door shut and locked the same as when I left it; I did not examine the warehouse - I went up stairs again; my father afterwards sent me down stairs to fill the tea-kettle - the kitchen is on the same floor as the warehouse - and as I went by I saw the back door about half way open; I called to my father, went into the warehouse directly, and perceived some drawers lying on the counters - they had been in their places before; all the things were gone out of them; they were the drawers from where the silk or bobbins were taken - my father missed the property; the ribbons were kept in the drawers on the left-hand side - those drawers were not taken out of their places; I had the key of the back door in my pocket - nobody could have got in without forcing it; I know the prisoner, he came to the warehouse that same evening, about two hours before I left the house, to pay me 5s. which he owed my father for cottons he had bought; he knew the house, and often came there - he used to come into the warehouse.

Cross-examined. Q. How long did he stay in the warehouse that night? A. Two or three minutes; he has staid as long as that before; I did not suspect any harm of him; I locked the front and back door - the servant could go down a flight of stairs and go out without coming to the warehouse; it is a large house - there are four rooms and a shop.
Q. A noise made in one part might easily be heard in the other? A. Yes; at night the servants were up stairs.

JOHN APPLEBY
. I live at No. 9, Vine - court, Lamb-street, Spitalfields, which is about ten minutes walk from the prosecutor's. I knew the prisoner - I saw him about three weeks after the robbery; he asked me to dispose of two pieces of work for him - he is a weaver ; the work was silk and cotton - I had them to sell for him - they are hatters bands; I have a brother in the business, and told him I must send them to him - he told me to do so; my brother would not have them as they were not perfect work; I went and tried to sell them - in two or three days I exchanged one of the pieces with Mr. Holmes, of Whitechapel; I was sent for, and went to the public-house Towers has mentioned, and there shewed him a piece of hatters band which Towers claimed; I had received it from the prisoner, and told him so.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner's business? A. Yes; he is a silk-weaver, and has manufactured his own work; I have known him manufacture hatters' hands - that is never called ribbon; Towers had heard I had the goods to sell - he did not suspect me.
JURY. Q. Were you in the habit of seeing the prisoner frequently before the robbery? A. I had not seen him for fifteen months before, and then he was in my employ for two or three years.
Q. Is there any difference between these goods and what he made? A. He could manufacture such goods; I cannot tell the difference between his manufacture and another.

ELIZABETH FOUNTAIN
. I am twelve years old. (This witness appeared perfectly to understand the nature of an oath.) I live at No. 45, Phoenix-street, with my father and mother - I know the prisoner, but not before the robbery; I live next door to Mr. Towers - I am not sure he is the man I saw; Towers' house was broken open on the Saturday night, and on that night I saw this young man come from up the court; I am not sure he is the man - he came from up the court and went across the street (Towers' back door opens into that court) - it was a little after eight o'clock; he had a bundle under his arm; I saw a man with a long brown great coat come up the court about two or three minutes after - he came from the same court as the person whom I took to be the prisoner - it was the first one who had the bundle; I saw a man with a red coat and a shiny hat walking up and down by the prosecutor's street-door; that man went towards Brick-lane, the other two wentup Farthing-street - I did not follow either of them; I was cleaning the threshold of the door - I saw Towers and his son that night, and told them what I had seen; I told Towers how the man with the bundle was dressed - which was in a blue coat, but that I was not sure that I should know him again; I saw the prisoner at Worship-street, and told the gentlemen that I was not sure it was him - and that I did not think it was him.
JURY. Q. Is the court a thoroughfare? A. No; there are about eight houses - the doors of which open to the court.

DANIEL HICKS
. I am shopman to Mr. Holmes, a hatter, of Aldgate. I bought some trimmings of Appleby; they were silk and cotton hat-bands - the officer received them from me.

THOMAS WATERS
. I am a Police-officer of Worship-street. On the 17th of March I took the prisoner at his own house in Princes-court, Gibraltar-walk, Bethnal-green; I asked him if he had sold any ribbon or hat-hands to Appleby - he said he had; I asked him where he got it - he said he found it about a fortnight ago on Farthing-hill; I shewed him one of them; I told him I should take him on suspicion of the robbery - Towers was with me; he denied the charge - I went up stairs to the room which he said he lived in, and found a quantity of cotton and a small quantity of silk, some in skeins and some on bobbins; he said they were all his own, and he had bought them; I told him he had better produce the bill of parcel before the Magistrate; the prosecutor said he had lost things of the quality, but would not swear to them; he identified the pieces of hands before the Magistrate - I got one of them from Hicks, and the other from the prosecutor himself.

JOHN TOWERS
. These hat-bands were manufactured by a person I employed; I know the make, because it is one colour on the edge, and another on the body of the work; it was returned to my hands by Appleby's brother a month before the robbery - it was damaged, which was the reason I had them laying by me; I am certain they were in my own possession before the house was broken open - the person who manufactured them is not here; I had seen it that day in a large drawer, with thirty-two pieces, which were taken at the same time (looking at the hat-band); the drawer they were in was about half way open, and the lock hanging on one screw; it was in its proper state when I left the house - the prisoner's father was taken into custody, and discharged; he had never worked for me - some things were found in a room in the father's house, but the prisoner said he rented it of his father.

MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How many locks of drawers had been forced open? A. Only one; it had been done without much noise, for they had laid mats on the floor, to prevent their being heard - a noise would not be heard on the top story; we had a suspicion of the very man who manufactured these, but did not have him taken up; he had an opportunity of knowing the premises - he did not work for me at the time, and did not come above once a week - it is two years since he worked for me; he then worked in my shop - what I speak to this by is the difference in colour; it was a mistake of mine in putting two colours in - I never saw such before, nor has any other man I should think; I heard the noise about eight o'clock- I only heard one noise.

JURY. Q. Had you sold them to Appleby's brother? A. He ordered it of me, and returned it on my bands on account of the badness of colour; and after the robbery they were taken to his brother for sale; he knew it, and gave me information.

JOHN APPLEBY
re-examined. Q. Is that the band you received from the prisoner, and offered to your brother, which he rejected? A. This is one of them - I did not take them to my brother, but sent them to him; he did not choose to have them; I could tell they were not well manufactured the instant I saw them; I shewed them to several hatters, who rejected them, as being badly made.
Cross-examined. Q. Is that the first badly manufactured article you ever saw? A. No, nor the last.

JURY. Q. Did you ever see any with the same defect in it? A. Never exactly, but very similar; it would be foolish to manufacture as this is - the body of the work is good, but the edges are another colour, thick, and clumsy; it is possible to make the same mistake.

JOHN TOWERS
. The value of the property taken is 20l. and upwards; the articles mentioned are worth about 20l.
Prisoner. I leave my Defence to my Counsel.

JAMES ABERY
. I remember the 14th of February. I saw the prisoner at half-past three o'clock that afternoon, and until eight in the evening, at the Half Moon public-house, in Bacon-street, Bethnal-green, which is no great way from Phoenix-street; I can walk it in five minutes - nothing particular occurred to make me remember the date; I left the place at eight o'clock, leaving him behind me there.

COURT. Q. What day was it? A. It was on a Saturday - I do not wear a watch; Spitalfield's church bell rings at eight o'clock, and it rang as I was going home; I left as it was ringing; it always strikes out at eight - I left while it was sounding.

ROBERT LOBB
. I am a broad silk-weaver. I know the prisoner, and saw him on the 14th of February, about half-past six o'clock in the evening, at the Half Moon; I found him there when I went in - I staid there till ten- he went away about eight, while the bell was ringing.
JURY. Q. How long was it before you saw him again? A. The next Saturday - I have known him six years.

WILLIAM LOBB
. I am brother to the last witness. I saw the prisoner at the Half Moon; I was with my brother - I went there about a quarter before seven, and remained there with the prisoner till a little after eight o'clock; he then went away - it might be five minutes past eight; the bell rings till a quarter past eight.

COURT. Q. Did you look at the public-house clock? A. Yes, I am quite sure of that; I generally look at the clock - the prisoner went away about five minutes, or it might be two or three minutes after eight; the Half Moon is about one hundred or one hundred and fifty yards from the prosecutor's house.

ROBERT BENNETT
. I am a broad silk-weaver. I saw the prisoner at the Half Moon on the 14th of February; I went about half-past six o'clock, and he went away near upon eight.
COURT. Q. Do you mean a little short of eight? A. About that - I am certain be staid till eight.

ELIZABETH SMITH. My husband is a silk-manufacturer. I have known the prisoner nearly six years, and he bore a very good character; I saw him at my house on the 14th of February; I live at No. 19, Fashion-street, Bethnal-green.

Q. At what time did you see him? A. My husband had just come home from work; it had just gone eight o'clock when he came and knocked at our door, and remained there with my piece, while I went to market, and stopped with me, when I came back, till twenty minutes past nine; I then went with him to his mother's, to lend her my cloak.

Q. At what time did you go out to market? A. Just as the bell had done ringing eight - he came in as I went out: my house is about two hundred yards from the Half Moon; the bell generally rings a quarter of an hour - I left him in the house, and found him there when I returned.

COURT. Q. On what day was this? A. Saturday, about a month before he was taken up; I was at Worship-street when he was examined - but was not called in; I recollect it was Saturday, the 14th, because my niece's birth-day was the next day - I do not recollect that Saturday by any particular name; he frequently visited us, being a neighbour's child - he came two or three times a week; I had nothing particular to induce me to recollect the day more than I have said.

Q. If he was in the habit of calling on other days, why do you recollect that day? A. Yes; but that night he did not wish me good night, as I had to go to his mother's to take her a cloak; I do not keep my niece's birth day - I did not invite any friends.

Q. What then makes you recollect it was the Saturday before her birth-day? A. I heard of this robbery being done on the following week - I did not hear he was suspected for a month after; I have no particular reason for recollecting his calling that night - he called on other Saturdays; his mother came that day to ask me to lend her a cloak, to go to their uncle's next morning - that was about six o'clock in the evening - she had never borrowed it before.

Q. What enables you to say it was that particular Saturday? A. I have no particular reason; she returned it on Monday the 16th; I do not generally know the date of the month - I did not invite the prisoner or his mother to come on my niece's birth-day.

Q. Then is there any thing particular to lead you to remember the day, besides it being the day before your niece's birth-day? A. No - only she named to me that it was that day; the prisoner's mother told me it was Saturday the 14th; I have no reason for believing it was then, except from what she told me; the prisoner was taken up on a Tuesday, and after that his mother told me it was the day she borrowed the cloak.
Q. You would not have recollected it unless the mother told you? A. No - I should not.

HARRIET OSBORNE
. Q. Do you remember last Valentine-day, as you are a young woman? A. Yes, it was the 14th of February; the prisoner came to our house that day as the bell was ringing eight o'clock, and staid till nine, or a few minutes after; he never went out during that time: my aunt came in from market, and then I went out.

COURT. Q. When was your birth-day? A. On Sunday, the 15th; the prisoner often visited me - he was paying his addresses to me; he generally came on Saturdays more than on other days - but not at my aunt's house.

Q. Where then did you meet him? A. Not particularly on Saturday - I was not always at my aunt's; I lived there - I do not recollect his visiting me any where else; he sometimes met me at the corner of the street - not always at my aunt's; I recollect this day, because it was Valentine's-day, and my birth-day was the 15th - he did not come the next Saturday, not that I recollect; he did not come every Saturday.
Q. Did you miss him on any Saturday? A. Yes, but not on any particular Saturday.

Q. What makes you remember this Saturday? A. Because next day a neighbour's daughter told me Towers had been robbed overnight - she lives next door to Towers: I did not tell any body the prisoner was with me that night, because nothing was said about him - I heard of his being taken up on the day he was taken, and said he was with me from a few minutes past eight o'clock till nine; I told a good many people so - I told my aunt; I did not see him on the Sunday, as I went on the Sunday morning with a neighbour's daughter to Woolwich; I did not come home till Tuesday night, and then heard he was taken - I went to Worship-street, and saw him getting into the van: I told my mother and a great many more that he was with me on the night of the robbery - I did not tell any body at the office so; I did not know any one - I went to Clerkenwell on the Friday, the day after he was examined; I knew when he was to be examined again, but did not go to the office - my aunt went, and I staid at home; I did not think it would be of any use for me to go - I stopped at home to do the cleaning; my aunt went - she was not called - she knew I was in his company from eight o'clock to nine.
Seven witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 22.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury on account of his good character .
NEW COURT, Seventh Day.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

969.
ELIZABETH TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 gown, value 4s.; 1 shawl, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s., and 1 yard of black velvet, value 1s. , the goods of
Harriet Digby
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

970.
WILLIAM FLOWERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of March , 8 shillings , the monies of
John Pickering
.

JOHN PICKERING
. I am an engraver , and live in Duke-street, Bloomsbury. I have known the prisoner some time; I sent him to receive a bill of 8s. - I did not send him with any money; he was to receive it, and bring it to me.
NOT GUILTY .

971.
JANE CHAPPEL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Mark Cullingford
.

MARK CULLINGFORD
. I am a publican , and live in York-street, Marylebone
. The prisoner was brought to my house with this pot, which is mine; she was quite a stranger.

CHARLES SAGE
. On Thursday night last, I was informed a woman had taken a pot from the door; I went out, and followed the prisoner up William-street - I took her with this put under her shawl.

Prisoner's Defence. I stopped to tie up my stocking, a man and a woman came by; the man put his face close to mine, and I took up the pot which stood there merely to pretend that I stooped for that - I had not gone many yards when this gentleman took me.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

972.
MARY CONNELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , 2 half-crowns , the monies of
John Manuel
.

JOHN MANUEL
. I met the prisoner between nine and ten o'clock, on the 30th of March, in Sutton-street, Soho
; I did not know her before; she said, "Well my dear," or something to that effect; we went into a passage together, but were not there more than half a minute; I then put my hand to my pocket, and my money was all correct - I had four half-crowns and 2s.; she said,"Let us go up stairs;" we went up, and she began to feel about my person, as we were on the first landing-place; we did not go into any room; I heard some money chink in her hand - I put my hand into my pocket, and missed two half-crowns; I accused her of the theft, and she dropped one halfpenny down the stairs, offered me another, and said there was my money; I said it was not, for I had lost two half-crowns; we came down stairs, and she called the watchman; I held her till the watchman came and searched her, but no half-crowns us were found; they had been in my right-hand waistcoat pocket, and could not have fallen out - I am quite sure she took them out; I had no halfpence about me; she said something about a shilling as we were going along; I was sober.

JOHN FRENCH
. I am a watchman. I searched the prisoner as far as decency would allow; but found nothing on her - the prosecutor was quite sober, and stated the same as he has now.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going for some starch; he dragged me on the stairs; I said it was not the first time he had accused me wrongfully; he said he would transport me; I had a 1d. in my hand - he said on the stairs he would give me so and so: he had me here before for 4s. a year and a half ago, when I first came from Ireland; he was dragging me along, and the halfpence fell from me.

JOHN MANUEL
. Upon my oath, I never saw the girl before; I never was before a Magistrate before in my life; there were a number of people round her.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

973.
CHARLES DUNN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of April , 1 ham, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Barford
.

GEORGE ALLEN
. I know Mr. Barford, a cheesemonger of East-street
. About ten minutes before ten o'clock, on the 9th of April, I saw the prisoner and another come by- the other lad crossed, took this ham, and gave it to the prisoner, who put it under his coat, and walked off with it; a neighbour gave information to the prosecutor, who came out and pursued him; I saw the prisoner throw down the ham in Spring-street, and the watchman took him.

GEORGE HAWKER
. I am a watchman. I took took the prisoner.

THOMAS BARFORD
. This is my ham.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

974.
JOHN HUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 1 coat, value 5s. the goods of
Richard Edwards
.

RICHARD EDWARDS
. I drive a cabriolet . I lost my coat on the 5th of April, out of my master's stable, in John-street, Tottenham-court-road
; the door was shut but not locked - the gates were locked; I left it safe about half-past ten o'clock at night - I have seen the prisoner in the yard several times - he went out two or three times as odd man for my master ; he knew the yard very well - there were five or six coats taken at the same time, and I believe ten whips: I found mine on Salter.

CHARLES SALTER
. I am a hackney-coachman. I bought this coat of the prisoner last Monday week, in the evening - he wanted 5s., but agreed to let me have it for 3s. 6d.; it is old and torn.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought three coats and ten whips in the Old Bailey, on the Saturday night, of a man in a New market cut-off coat; I sold two coats to a Jew.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

975.
JAMES KNOWLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of February , 5 sovereigns and 1 half sovereigns , the monies of
William Povey
.

WILLIAM POVEY
, JUN. I drive the Stroundwater coach . Mr. Lawerence asked me to bring this money to Mr. Van, of Tooley-street: the prisoner had acted as porter to the coaches at the Bull inn, to which I came - I did not hear from Mr. Van, and on the Sunday morning I sent the prisoner to him to know if he would come; he returned and said, Mr. Van said if I would send the money over by him he would pay him - I gave him five sovereigns and one half-sovereigns, to take to Mr. Van; he did not return, and I wrote to Mr. Van to know if he had seen him.
Prisoner. Q. Have I not a great many times been intrusted with your money? A. Yes.

THOMAS VAN
. The money never came to my hands; some of my family desired the prisoner to receive the money, but I was gone to church - I do not know whether the prisoner is the person who came; I do not know that any person authorised him to go for it on my account.
NOT GUILTY .

976.
JOHN PAYNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 3 pairs of pinching-irons, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Gregory
.

ANGELIOUS BETRAUN
. I am an officer. About half-past four o'clock on the 10th of April, I was on duty, and saw the prisoner and another lad - I followed them to Portland-street, where I saw the prisoner open the prosecutor's shop door and go in; he came out with something in his apron and joined his companion - I went after the prisoner, who was stopped and brought back, and in his coat pocket were these irons.

THOMAS GREGORY
. These irons are my property.
GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Whipped and Discharged.

977.
MARY WELLS
,
TAMER SEETON
, and
ELIZABETH BERRY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April , 1 gown, value 5s. , the goods of
John Russell Law
.

CHARLES MILLS
. I live with Mr. John Russell Law, a pawnbroker of Commercial-road
. On the 8th of April Seeton and Wells came to our shop to pawn a dressing-case, which I would not take in - this gown was hanging up in the shop, but I did not observe them go near it; they came to the counter - the gown was near the counter; when they were gone I missed it; my suspicion fell on the two women - I went out, and found Berry about seven doors off with the gown under her shawl, at the corner of Berners-street; she had not been to the house - I said she must come with me to the shop; she said she was to have 6d. for carrying it, and pointed us to two women, but I did not observe them - I did not hear her say the word"Women;" I said before the Magistrate that she said two women had given her 6d. to carry it - she did say so; I brought her back to the shop; the officer took the other woman.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Berry mentioned that two women had given it her? A. I did not observe them - I did not see her point; she told me she pointed - there were two other persons in the shop, but they remained till I got back.
COURT. Q. Is it a long counter? A. Yes; it might have been taken by one without the other knowing it - I could not see who took it.

JAMES FOGG
. I took Berry in charge with this gown; she said, "I did not steal it; Wells gave it to my sister Tamer, and she gave it me." I then went to Seeton's mother, and found Seeton there; I told her I wanted her and Mrs. Wells - she began to cry, and said "You have got Bet at the office for stealing a gown; but I am the thief, and she shall not suffer innocently - I took the gown from Laws, and they know it;" there was no promise or threat made to her - I had not been in the house a moment.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to say she told you this story without your saying any thing to induce her? A. Yes; I knew her before, and she knew I was an officer - I believe she has three or four children.

JOHN ADAMS
. I am an officer. We went, and took Wells after we had taken Seeton - Wells denied all knowledge of it; Seeton and Berry are sisters.(Property produced and sworn to.)
WELLS' Defence. I am innocent - I never saw the people till I went to the office.
SEETON's Defence. I am innocent.

JOHN MILLER
. I am a waterman. I was standing at the corner of Berners-street talking to Berry, Seeton came up and said, "I have bought a gown Betsey, will you carry it for me under your shawl, and it will not get wet;" she took it, and they walked down the street.
Q. Do you live with either of them? A. I live close by- we have drank together; nothing was said about a sixpence - it rained very hard.
Q. She said she had bought the gown? A. Yes, for 4s.; they are sisters - I did not see Wells there; Berry desired me to come here - I was not before the Magistrate.

SEETON -
GUILTY . Aged 26.

BERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

WELLS -
NOT GUILTY .

978.
ANN CORDWELL
,
THOMAS PURDY
, and
GEORGE HILL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 3 sheets, value 11s; 2 petticoats, value 2s.; 6 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; and 1 shift, value 1s., the goods of the
overseers of the poor, for the time being, of the parish of Fulham
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the property of
Sarah Battershill
.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

SARAH BATTERSHILL
. I am matron of Fulham work-house
. On the 16th of March the three prisoners were paupers
there: I was absent for some time on parish business - I left the prisoners there, and when I returned they had absconded, about ten minutes, as I heard; I did not miss any property till the Tuesday night, when the officer took one of the prisoners, with a bundle; I knew the property - it had been in my care in the work-house.

ELIZABETH CHARLES
. On Monday, the 16th of March, I saw Stokes, Cordwell, and Purdy, (but not Hill) with a bundle, which they all assisted to carry from the workhouse to the Rose and Crown public-house, at Putney; Stokes and Cordwell pawned some sheets at Mr. Steward's; we then went to the King's Arms; Stokes and I went to Mr. Butcher's, a pawnbroker's, at Wandsworth, and pawned a shirt for 2s., three flannel petticoats for 1s. 6d., a shift for 8s., and a handkerchief for 1s.; we then went back to the King's Arms public-house, and all four of us had breakfast; Cordwell and Purdy were there - they knew how we had disposed of the things, but Hill was not there at all; an officer came and took them into custody, and took Purdy with a bundle, but he did not take me; I went and gave information; Hill was in the house, but I do not know that he did any thing; I did not see these people steal the things.

JOSEPH ROSE
. I am a constable. On the 17th of March I saw Purdy at Fulham, and took him, with a bundle -I asked how he came by it - he said I had better see; I shewed it to the matron.

ISAAC HAWKINS
. I went to Mr. Steward's, and got two sheets belonging to the poor-house; Mrs. Battershill took me there; I then went to Mr. Butcher's, and got these other articles.

THOMAS ASHBY
. I know the poor-house. On the 16th of March, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw Elizabeth Charles, Stokes, and Purdy, on the top of the premises - Hill was at the bottom, throwing up the bundles to Purdy; the matron was out of the way at the time; the prisoners left the house the same evening.(Property produced and sworn to.)

CORDWELL's Defence. We were washing on Monday afternoon; after tea, Stokes asked us to go away, and said she would get us work, and keep us till we got it; Charles then went into the yard, and got the linen - they were put in bundles, and at night we got over the wall: we went to Putney, and there they pawned two sheets; we then went to Wandsworth - we slept at the King's Arms; on the Monday morning they pawned one sheet at Mr. Butcher's, and two flannel petticoats, one shirt, and three hankerchiefs; Charles pawned the handkerchiefs in her own name, and Stokes the rest: we went to Chelsea next day, and then Stokes took two old sheets, and sold them, but I do not know to whom: on the Tuesday they ran away, and I never saw them till Thursday, when I saw Stokes, and asked what she had done with the duplicates; she he had said, burnt them; I was away a fortnight, and then I thought I had better give myself up, and suffer a little, and give up the company I was in.

PURDY's Defence. Stokes asked if I would run away? I said, I had such a bad jacket; she said, "I will buy you a jacket in Chelsea;" Stokes tied up the bundles; I saw them take three pieces of soap, which they sold in Jew's-row; they then went to the Rose and Crown public-house, and took the shirts - I was going away, but they would not let me.
HILL's Defence. I was down in the garden while the other prisoners were getting over; I asked where they were going? they did not answer; I never went away.

CORDWELL -
GUILTY . Aged 30.

PURDY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

HILL -
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

979.
JOHN TAYLOR
and
BENJAMIN TAYLOR
were indicted for
breaking and entering a certain building, within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
Edward Chattaway
, and occupied therewith, but not being part thereof, on the 11th of April , and stealing therein 5 live tame fowls, price 16s., his property .
MR. DOWLING conducted the prosecution.

EDWARD CHATTAWAY
. I keep the workhouse at Edmonton
. On the 10th of April I had some fowls in a hen-house at the corner of the workhouse yard; it is surrounded with a wall nine or ten feet high; on the 11th I missed five fowls, which I had seen the day before - I have not seen them again; the tiles of the hen-house were taken off: they had tried to get in by the door, and could not. I saw the prisoners apprehended; Benjamin Taylor had a plaid cap on.

Prisoner
BENJAMIN TAYLOR
. Q. Is there not more than one cap of a kind? A. Yes - I cannot say that I ever saw you with a cap on before; your brother wore one similar so it.

ELIZABETH HART
. (This witness being deaf and dumb, gave her evidence through a person who could communicate with her.) I am a pauper in the workhouse
at Edmonton; I know both the prisoners - they had been paupers there: on Saturday morning last I got out of bed and looked out of the window - it was a beautiful morning; I saw one of the prisoners on the wall, and the other on the ground, within the wall; there was another person with them, whom I did not know - one of the prisoners had a fowl, with its beak in his hand; the wings fluttered and he put it under his arm - I am quite sure the prisoners were two of the men: I rapped at the window, and described the prisoners to the master; Benjamin had a striped cap on his head.

Prisoner
BENJAMIN TAYLOR
. Q. Did you see me on the top of the wall? A. I saw him getting over the wall, I am quite certain - I did not see him take the tiles off.

JOHN CAMP
. I am a constable. I took Benjamin Taylor, with this cap on his head; I have seen him wear it before.

JOHN TAYLOR
'S Defence. I was in bed and asleep at the time.

JAMES TAYLOR
. I am the prisoners' father; they lodge at my house. On the night of Friday last I went home at half-past eight o'clock, and inquired if Benjamin had come in - my wife said he had: while I was eating my supper John came in, had his supper, and went to bed - when I got up the next morning, at six o'clock, they were both in bed: my house is a mile from the prosecutor's.

- TAYLOR. I am the prisoners' sister. My brother Benjamin was at home when my father came in; John then came in, and sat down - when they went to bed I locked the door, and took the key out; when I got up in the morning they were in bed - the key had laid on a chair in my bed room.
MR. DOWLING. Q. Were you ever in the House of Correction? A. Yes, once, for a few potatoes, and once for some gooseberries, which I had given to me.
NOT GUILTY .

980.
JOHN GOODRICK
and
ROBERT GOODRICK
were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of Harry Phillips on the 3d of April , and stealing therein 12 drinking-glasses, value 18s.; 12 plates, value 12s.; 5 dishes, value 10s., and I looking-glass, value 10l., the goods of the said
Harry Phillips
.
MR. CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

MARY ANN BROWN
. I am servant to Mr.
Harry Phillips
, and had the care of his house, which is Brandenburgh college, at Fulham, Middlesex
. On the night of the 2d of April I locked up the house all safe - the next morning I went to open it, and found the door open and a chair against it; the shutters were put too, but the padlock which I had put on at night was broken off and gone; I looked in the kitchen, found the drawers all open, and the china and glass gone, which I had seen right the night before - I missed the chimney-glass from over the drawing-room fire-place, where I had laid the fire the day before; this iron bar laid across the fire-place, it appears to be the same the house was broken with.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there any other servant in the house? A. No one slept in the house- I locked it outside, and went away; Mr. Phillips did not live in the house at all - it was left in my care: Mr. Phillips makes use of it at different times - he frequently drank tea there, and used those glasses when he was there.

JOSEPH PALMER
. I know the two prisoners - they live at Hammersmith: I went to their house with a search warrant, on the 3rd of April, with a man of the name of Hallett and Mr. Phillips - I went up stairs, and was going into the room on the first floor, but was prevented by John Goodrick and his wife, who said there was a woman who had lain in but a few days - I said I must insist upon it; they begged me to wait a few minutes while they got the room fit for a man to go into - I placed a man at the door, and went up stairs; I found no property relating to this indictment; I came down again, and with very great reluctance they let me go into the room - in fact I was obliged to force my way in; I proceeded to search every part till I came to the bed: I lifted up one corner of the bed, and saw the mattress - I then went to the other corner; I saw nothing there - as I was putting it down again, I saw a small hole in the straw mattress, I put my hand in, and felt a plate or a dish; I pulled it out - Mr. Phillips claimed it; I put in my hand, and found I believe, seven, which I put into Mr. Phillip's hand, who identified them; John Goodrick took up the plates and dishes, smashed them on the floor, and said "There you b-rs, now can you swear to them;"I called for assistance - John Goodrich got the poker, and said he would smash my b-y brains out; Robert Goodrick then ran up, passed my man on the stairs, and caught up another poker - John said "Come on Bob, let us beat their h-y brains out, if they do not get out of the house;" I got out, and sent for three of my own men - the prisoners were then apprehended, I found a dark lantern and a cutlas, but nothing more relating to this indictment.

Cross-examined. Q. Robert did not come up till there was a row? A. As soon as I called for my assistant, Robert ran up, and passed him; I believe John is married, and has one or two children - these are the broken plates and dishes.

MR. PHILLIPS. I am son of
Harry Phillips
. I was with Palmer; what he has stated is correct - there was a woman in bed.
Cross-examined. Q. Is there any private marks on these plates and dishes? A. No; I was perfectly aware this was my father's property, when it was taken from the bed.

WILLIAM HALLETT
. I was charged to aid and assist Palmer to search the house; what he has stated is correct.

ANN BROWN
re-examined. It was a large sized glass; it filled the fire place - this is a fruit-dish that matches with what were taken; I think we lost five dishes, nine or ten plates, and some glasses.

JOHN GOODRICK
's Defence. They say it is a dwelling-house, when I know the house has been locked up for months and months, and not a soul has been seen there, but the woman has come and unlocked it in the morning, to give it air; it is a summer-house, about four hundred yards from the dwelling-house - I have had that dark-lantern for many years; I use it in the boat, to sort my fish at Billingsgate, in the winter.

JOHN GOODRICK
- GUILTY. Aged 30.

ROBERT GOODRICK
- GUILTY. Aged 21.

Of Stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years . There was another indictment against the prisoners, which was not tried.

981.
JOHN BLACKALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 cask, value 2s. , the goods of
James Buckland
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

982.
ELIZABETH DALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 3 spoons, value 5s. , the goods of the Rev .
Peter Moody
, clerk.

MARGARET WOODBURN
. I am servant to the Rev. Peter Moody. The prisoner came into the kitchen on Tuesday morning last - I was absent at the time; when I came down she begged me to buy some matches - I missed the spoons, searched her basket and found them under her shawl.

HENRY COOPER
. I am an officer. I produce the spoons, which I took from the prisoner.
GUILTY. Aged 12.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, on account of her youth .
Judgment Respited .
Second London Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

979.
ANN HANDS
,
NICHOLAS BROWN
, and
BRIDGET LANE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , 36 curb-chains, value 12s.; 73 curb-books, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
William Benton
.

WILLIAM BENTON
. I am an ironmonger , and live in a court in Whitecross-street. On the 1st of April I went with these things to a public-house, to speak to a friend, and set my bundle on a cask by the side of the bar; I missed it in a minute; I went to the door, and a person said if any body has taken your bundle it is two women and a man, who are gone along Beech-street
; we went along there, into the French Horn public-house, and saw the three prisoners there together; I said, "It is very strange my bundle is gone, and no one has been in the house but yourselves;" Brown and Lane said, "We have no bundle" - Hands said nothing; in about a minute and a half I saw my bundle under Hand's shawl; I said,"You are a bad woman, here is my bundle;" "Here is your bundle," said she.

JOHN AXE
. I am a shoemaker. I was in the King's Arms, and saw the three prisoners there; they had a quartern of gin; I did not see the bundle taken - I came out with them, and saw them go on towards the French Horn, in Beech-street; when the bundle was missed, I went in, and said it must have been taken by the two women and the man who had been leaning against the cask; I followed them into the French Horn, and asked if they had taken a bundle by mistake from the Cat, as it is called; they said they had not; but the prosecutor and the officer went in, and Hands gave it up.

JOSEPH ORTON
. I was coming by, and went into the public-house; Hands said, "This is your bundle, take it;" I said I should take her into custody - "Brown said,"You have got your bundle, what more do you want;"on going to the Compter, Hands said Brown gave it her; he denied it - he was very much intoxicated.

THOMAS JONES
. I am a constable. I was sent for to assist to take the prisoners; Hands said that Brown took took the bundle, and brought it to the door; Brown said,"O you wicked woman, I never did such a thing.
Hands put in a written defence, stating that Brown had given her the bundle to carry.

HANDS -
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined One Month .

BROWN -
NOT GUILTY .

LANE -
NOT GUILTY .

984.
WILLIAM PEACH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , 2 segar-boxes, value 6d., and 5 ozs. weight of segars, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Francis Francis
.

FRANCIS FRANCIS
. I am a tobacconist . On the 5th of March I went out, at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, and missed these segars, at a quarter before eleven, from my shop-window; I know nothing of the prisoner; these boxes have my writing on them.

JOHN CARLILE
. I saw the prisoner, and two others, on the 5th of March, about ten o'clock in the morning - the prisoner had one of these boxes, with a blue apron over it, and one of the others had one; they came down Aldersgate-street, and went up Jewin-crescent; I saw them taking some out of the boxes, and putting them into their pockets - I went up, and they all ran off; I took the prisoner; I picked up this one segar at the corner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going along St. Martin's-le-grand, and a man asked me to buy two boxes; I said, No; he then asked me if I kept white mice; I said, No, I kept nothing of the kind; but I bought the boxes for 6d., for my brother to keep silk in.
JOHN CARLILE re-examined. Q. Did he say this at the time? A. No; he threw down his box, and so did the other - the prisoner was very violent indeed; he kicked, tore, and fought me.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.

985.
THOMAS SUMMERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , 1 shawl, value 2s. , the goods of
Ann Belcher
.

The
prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

986.
CAROLINE JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March , 1 kettle, value 10s., and 1 flat-iron, value 6d. , the goods of
William Carryer
.

JAMES MONKS. I am a bricklayer. I was at work in a passage near Red Lion-market
, on the 19th of March; I saw the prisoner come down the passage without any thing - she walked up the passage again, to the yard-door of the house, and went into the yard; I was about a dozen yards from her; I got down, and looked at her in the yard; I went up again to my work, and for about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes I watched the place, but no one came; I then sent the labourer to see if any one was in the water-closet - he said there was not, but the flapdoor was open; I said it had been shut before, I went, and the flap was up; in about half an hour I saw the prisoner coming out - I knew she was the person who went in; the wind nearly blew her bonnet off, and she put her hands to keep it on - she asked the way to Bunhill-row, and we directed her; I then saw she had a bundle in her left-hand; I called her, but she did not come - I sent the labourer to bring her back - we inquired for the prosecutor; his servant came, and we found on the prisoner this kettle and flat-iron.
Prisoner. Q. Was I not intoxicated? A. She was rather tipsy - this was between two and three o'clock in the afternoon.

EUPHEMIA NESS
. I am servant to Mr. William Carryer. Monks called me - I found the prisoner; I asked what she had got; she said, "Nothing of ours;" I said, "Let me look under your cloak," and found this kettle and flat-iron; the kettle had been taken from under the dresser in the front-kitchen, and the iron from the mantel-piece.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 33.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Seven Days .

987.
HUGH ELLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., and 1 pair of boots, value 4s., the goods of
James Smetzer
, his master .

JAMES SMETZER
. I am a shoemaker . I have employed the prisoner occasionally; I employed him on the 28th of March; he left at near twelve o'clock at night. On Wednesday, the 1st of April, I missed a pair of shoes out of a lot of sixty-nine pairs, which I had had in on the Monday night - I did not miss my boots, but I have seen them and the shoes since, and can swear to them.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. The shoes, you say. you think are part of a lot that came in on the Monday? A. This pair of shoes are not one of the sixty-nine pair -I could not state these were on my premises on the Saturday; the prisoner had eight or nine shillings a week, and sometimes as little as six; I always considered him honest - there is a mark on the shoes.

STEPHEN STEVENS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of shoes and a pair of boots pawned on the 28th of March by the prisoner.

JOHN CURTIS
. I took the prisoner, and found this duplicate on him, which relates to these other shoes which were found at another pawnbroker's.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Six Months .

988.
HENRY RAFFIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 5 pairs of shoes, value 9s. 6d., and I pair of boots, value 16s., the goods of
Joseph Preston
, his master .

JOSEPH PRESTON
. I keep a shop in Seacoal-lane
-The prisoner was in my employ on the 1st of March, and on the 3d of March I missed my boots and shoes, which were safe in my shop about twelve o'clock on the 2d of March; I was in the habit of taking my goods home at night, and when I went that night I could not get admittance - the next morning I sent my lad for the goods; he came back, and gave me information - I went, and we could not get in; I went with an officer in the evening, about ten o'clock - the property was gone; we raised a ladder, and found the prisoner in a top room.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How long has the shop been opened? A. I think about a fortnight; it had been empty, but I do not know that loose persons went to sleep there - the prisoner used to sleep there; I had his direction from his brother, and had him taken into custody - I live in Moor-lane.

CHARLES SENIOR
. I am a boot and shoemaker. On the 2d or 3d of March, a man came into my shop with five pairs of mended-up shoes, and asked my 6s. for them - I gave him 5s.; on the 5th of March the prosecutor came and claimed one pair of them; I bought them of a man a good deal like the prisoner, but cannot swear it was him.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q Are you in the habit of buying of many persons who hawk shoes about? A. Yes.

JAMES BARNET
. On the 2d of March, in the evening, I bought this pair of boots, but I do not know of whom - it was a person I never saw before; I do not think the prisoner is the person - I said so before the Magistrate, because the person - I bought them of was very dirty; he was about the prisoner's size - I do not think he is the man.

ANTHONY REPTON
. I took the prisoner in Maidenhead-court; I received these boots from Barnet, who said he bought them of the prisoner - the prisoner made no answer.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

989.
JOSEPH GORDON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March . 1 mahogany plank, value 2l., the goods of
Henry Peto
and another .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

990.
CHARLES COX
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

ANN HAZEL
. I am the wife of
James Hazel
- we live in Jewin-street
. On the 24th of February the prisoner came to our shop, and offered what appeared to be a half-sovereign, in payment for a milliner's doll, which came to 2s. 6d; I gave him 7s. 6d. change - I put the half-sovereign into my till; there was no other money there - I afterwards gave it to Mr. Harris.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you sure there was no other money in the till? A. Yes - I gave the change from my pocket: I did not know him before- I am not mistaken in his person.

JAMES HARRIS
. I was in the room adjoining the shop - Hazell showed me this coin; I pursued, and took the prisoner, who had gone through some courts leading to Whitecross-street - he was walking; I said we wanted him, he had been passing a bad half-sovereign - he said,"If it is a had one, I took it, and don't want any brother about it, I will give you another;" I said, "We think you knew it was a bad one" - we took him into a public-house, where the officer took him.

DANIEL USALL
. I am a haberdasher, and live in Aldersgate-street. On the 24th of February, between twelve and one o'clock, the prisoner came to look at a pair of gloves; he selected a pair, and threw down what appeared to be a half-sovereign - I said we had not change; he said, "I will call again in a few minutes, if you will wrap them up, and get me a riding-belt in the mean time" - I followed him, and watched him into Hazel's shop; there was another person with him.

WILLIAM BETTERTON
. I took the prisoner, and produce this half-sovereign, as it appears to be.

JOHN FIELD
. I am inspector of counterfeit coin - this is a gilt sixpence.
NOT GUILTY .

991.
JOHN WILKINSON
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .

992.
WILLIAM PERRY
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

DANIEL THORN
. I am in the service of Mr.
Edward Pontifex
and others; they are coppersmith s, and live in Shoe-lane
. On the 14th of March the prisoner came and brought this order, which he said he brought from
James Walker
- (read)
Order from J. Walker Harp-alley. 14th March, 1829. No. 876.
Please to let the bearer have, or send as soon as possible, two copper tea-kettles, one six quarts, and one four quarts.
W. SPARKES.

Mr.
William Sparkes
is foreman to Mr. Walker - this is very similar to his hand-writing; I let the prisoner have the kettles.

THOMAS JAMES FRANCIS
. I was in the public-house adjoining Worship-street office; the prisoner was brought in there - he sat down, and a man said to him,

"I am sorry to see you in such a situation;" the officer put some papers before him - one was an order for two tea-kettles, and one for some lead; the prisoner said he was not certain whether he signed the order for the two tea-kettles, but the one for four he did not sign - he said he had been drinking three or four days, and I believe he said he was stone blind drunk; he seemed absorbed in grief.

CHARLES JAMES WALKER
. I took the prisoner, and found these orders on him - one is for two tea-kettles, and one for lead; I did not hear the conversation just stated.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I searched the prisoner, and found these orders in his possession, and this bill for four kettles, which were got from Mr. Pontifex.

JAMES WALKER
. I am the employer of
William Sparks
. The prisoner has been in my employ - I discharged him five weeks ago; I did not give him any anthority to get these things; this order is not
william Sparkes
' writing - the orders were torn from my printed order-book, and are dated the day he left.
Prisoner's Defence. These orders were found in my hat - how I came by them I do not know; I was tipsy all day.

WILLIAM SPARKES
. This is not my writing - I never gave it to the prisoner; I never gave him any authority to write my name there.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

993.
GEORGE FREDERICK BROWN
was indicted for a
misdemeanour .
MR. BOLLAND conducted the prosecution.

JAMES CAYHILL
. I am shopman to
Mr . Watson
- he is a linen-draper , and lives at No. 55, Holborn-hill
. The prisoner was an apprentice to Mr. Trevethan, of Burton-cres -cent; his master had been a customer to us for some time: the prisoner had often been sent, and was well known to us. On the 2d of January he brought some patterns, and said he wanted one pieces of furniture of one pattern, and two of the other; one was tea and drab, and the other tea and red - I served him, and put up a remnant of tea and red with them; they all came to 6l. 15s. 10d.: this is the invoice - he went away with the goods.

ROBERT DUKE
. I found these invoices at the prisoner's mother's lodging, and a number of patterns of furniture prints.

JAMES CAYHILL
re-examined. On the 16th of January he came again, and had one piece of tea and red striped, two pieces of tea and green, which with the glazing made thewhole bill 6l. 10s. 8d. - this in the invoice. On the 6th of February he came again, and had one piece of tea and drab striped, the same as at first; he had one whole piece, and a large remnant of fifty-one yards of another pattern of ground chintz - they came to 7l. 9s. 9d.; this is the invoice. On the 27th of February he came again, and had one piece of light ground chintz, and said as there was not sufficient of the tea ground chintz, the light ground might he used instead; I put in that parcel a tremnant of forty-nine yards and a half - the bill was 9l. 17s. 2d.

WILLIAM TYLER
. I produce this invoice, and this note.

JAMES CAYHILL
. I gave the prisoner this note, and this is the invoice of the last article.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. Had you not instructions to deliver no goods without a written order? A. No; it is most frequently the case that young men produce a written order - not always.

SAMUEL TREVETHAN
. I am an upholsterer. The prisoner was my apprentice; I never gave him authority to get these goods, and never had them.

JOHN MOYLE
. I am shopman to Mr. Trevethan. I frequently give orders, but never gave the prisoner these orders, and never received the goods.

RICHARD LANGSTAFF
. I am in the service of Mr. Trevethan. I never gave the prisoner orders to get these goods.
Prisoner. Q. What goods did you send me for, for a job of your own at Peckham? A. I never did send for any.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Second London Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

994.
ANN THEW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 cloak, value 7s.; 1 gown, value 1s, 6d., and 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Martin
, her master .

WILLIAM MARTIN
. I am a schoolmaster , and live in Bull and Mouth-street
, The prisoner was in my service, about two months previous to the 13th of February, on which day she left me; we missed the articles stated, and found her about a fortnight afterwards, in Field-lane; the articles were found on her, except the shoes, which were in pawn.

JOSEPH WILLIAMS
. I am a constable. I went with the prosecutor to a house on Saffron-hill, where the prisoner was seen to go in; I inquired if there was a person of her name there - they said there was; I met her on the stairs, and asked her if her name was
Ann Thew
- she said No; I said I would not let her go till I got a light, as it was very dark: I found these articles in the room, not on her; I was told she lodged there - she said she had torn the lining out of the cloak, and threw it in the fire, and the gown was up stairs in the room; there was no threat or promise made to her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .
The prosecutor stated that he had missed other property which the prisoner acknowledged she had taken.
Second Middlesex Jury.

995.
GEORGE FRANKLIN
,
RICHARD HEMMINGS
, and
JOHN GRAY
, were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Atkins
, on the 29th of March , and stealing therein 2 pecks of onions, value 2s.; 2 casks, value 3s.; 4 gallons of shrub, value 30s.; 2 gallons of peppermint, value 1l.; 2 gallons of gin, value 18s.; 2 gallons of cloves, value 1l.; 3 gallons of Rum, value 30s., and 2 bottles, value 4d., the goods of the said
Thomas Atkins
.
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS ATKINS
. I keep the White Lion public-house, Dancer's-hill, South Mims
. My house was safe on the night of the 29th of March, and the cellars quite secure - the next morning, which was Sunday, I went to draw some ale - I saw the cellar broken open; the boards had been broken exactly where the bolts were, and they had put their arm in and drawn the bolts back; I can swear that I missed about ten gallons from different casks, of cloves, peppermint, shrub, rum, and gin - some ale, onions, casks, and stone bottles - one bottle had a little shrub in it, one a little ale, and one was empty; I sent off to Barnet for an officer, and we both examined the premises; a person called on me, and I went with my ostler, cooper, to the field, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon; I found five men drinking in the field, four of whom I knew - the prisoners were three of them; they were drinking ale out of a stonebottle - they all drank in their turns - it was such a bottle as I had lost; Franklin was sitting on one of the casks which I knew - I ordered my ostler to take three of the casks up, and Gray said, "Master took it out;" I said they were my casks - they said if they were mine I might take them; Franklin said they found them in the hedge - I got on the coach to go to Barnet, leaving them with one bottle, pouring ale out; Cooper took the casks to my house - I got two officers, went to South Mims, and found Gray in a chandler's-shop; we went to a cottage near where they had been drinking and found Franklin - my ostler and I then got on a coach, and took Hemmings about a mile on this side of St. Alban's.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This breaking open of your cellar took place on the night of the 29th of March? A. Yes; or early on the following morning; I went to bed about eleven o'clock, and was the last person up - the cellar is in the garden - it is not under the same roof as the house - there is a side door from the kitchen into it; it was open day-light when these men were sitting drinking - Gray asked me to pour some out for them - they were all pretty far gone; two or three of them seemed as if they were able to understand me; I believe the prisonerswere so tipsy that they did not know what they were about; there is a footpath near the place where they were, but they are bye fields - I went back to the spot where they had been, and brought away the other bottle; there was nothing to prevent our taking them - but I did not know I might without an officer.

JOHN COOPER
. I am the ostler. I went to the field in the afternoon, and found the three prisoners and the other men as my master has stated.

FREDERICK PROPSTEING
. I was applied to on the morning of the 29th, went in the evening to the chandler's-shop, and took Gray in South Mims; I kept him - and the others went and brought Franklin.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT.
EIGHTH DAY. SATURDAY, APRIL 18.
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Recorder.

996.
JOHN PETTET
,
JAMES WHITE
,
JAMES MARTIN
, and
SAMUEL HILLICK
were indicted
forfeloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Sarah Howorth
, on the 3d of April , at St. Luke, and stealing therein 2 tables, value 10s.; 4 chairs, value 10s., and 2 candlesticks, value 3s., the goods of Sarah Howorth; I trunk, value 10s., and 10 sovereigns, the property of
Joseph Bennet
; 2 chests of drawers, value 16s.; 2 coats, value 7s.; one pair of trousers, value 4s., and 40 fishing-lines, value 10s., the goods of
William Gardner
and another .
MESSERS. BOLLAND & CRESWELL conducted the prosecution.

SARAH HOWORTH
. I am single , and live at No. 42, Goswell-street, in the parish of St. Luke
; I have lived there thirty-five years - Mr. Robert Ray is the landlord, and has been so about twenty-one years. On the 3d of April I was at home, and in consequence of information I saw Pettet about half-past one o'clock in the passage of My house; he demanded 120l. for six years' back rent - I told him I did not owe any such money; I asked him to walk up stairs - he followed me up, accompanied by two more men, who I cannot identify; Pettet pulled out a paper, and read it - I do not know what it was; he then demanded the rent in the name of
William Chapman
- I should not know the paper again, for I did not have it; I never heard of William Chapman in my life - Pettet said his own name was John Smith; he asked me to open my lodger's door, whose name is Bennett - I told him I could not, for my lodger was out; his door was fastened with a padlock outside - I was very much alarmed; he told me not to flurry myself, for I should have five days to replevie if he was in the wrong - when I said I could not open Bennett's door, he said he could not wait a minute; I said, "I have another way backwards, if you will wait while I go round and see if that is open;" he said he should not wait a minute - he rushed by me, and wrenched the padlock off before my face; he went into the room, and the two men with him - I did not go into the room; I went down-stairs, and went out to look for my brother - I was absent nearly a quarter of an hour; when I came back there was a van at the door loaded with goods - I thought I saw a table on it which was mine; I did not notice any thing else - when I got into the house it was nearly empty, and the house was so full of people in the passage I could hardly get in; I found Mr. Butler there, who is the rent-gatherer for Mr. Ray - he has been so about ten or eleven years; I never knew any other rent - gather during that time - I had some conversation with Butler, and then fetched Hawthorne, the officer: he came back with me - Pettet was then standing at the post of the parloar-door, and I gave a charge of him - the constable asked him by what authority he took the goods; he refused to show his authority; he said he was not going; to have it turn up - two tables were taken out of the house, four chair, two brass candlesticks, one pair of cotton stockings, and some crockery; the house was nearly empty - I had never received any notice not to pay the rent to Butler.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Since you have been tenant of these premises has any person demanded rent from you, except Mr. Ray and Butler? A. Not since Mr. Ray has had the house; before that Mr. Barker did - I have not paid any rent for four years, because I have a little property which I cannot get at, and Mr. Ray is so kind as to wait for it; I am confident Pettet did not say he had come as an agent of Smith or by his authority - he said his own name was Smith; I was very much alarmed, but I am certain of that; he demanded the rent in the name of Chapman, and said his own name was Smith: he did not represent that he was acting for Smith; I first saw him in the passage; I think the door was shut when I saw him; the passage was full of people, when he refused to show his authority for fear it should be torn up - he did not say I should have a list of the articles taken away; he was asked for the inventory, and said he had got it, but would not show it.
MR. CRESWELL. Q. Who demanded to see the distresswarrant? A. Butler and the constable.

WILLIAM GARDNER
. I lodge at Miss Howorth's. I remember the Friday that these things were taken out of the house; I saw Pettet that day - there was a knock at the door, it was opened by a laid inside, and Pettet came in; he came along the passage to my door, and asked me for
Sarah Howorth
